Photocatalysis is widely recognized as a promising technique for addressing energy and environmental challenges. Exploring novel photocatalysts represents a crucial avenue for advancing the development of photocatalytic technology. Bismuth (Bi)-based photocatalysts have garnered significant attention due to their distinctive crystal structure, favorable hybrid electronic band structure and diverse composition. In recent years, numerous polynary Bi-based (PBB) photocatalysts have been investigated, which exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance. However, most reviews still primarily focus on summarizing traditional materials, it is necessary and urgent to provide a comprehensive review of emerging PBB photocatalysts reported in recent years. This review encompasses the latest advancements in emerging PBB photocatalysts over the past decade (approximately 60 species), covering crystal structure, synthesis method, modification approaches and application areas. This review provides a concise summary and offers insight into future research trends of emerging PBB photocatalysts and guidance for finding suitable applications based on their crystal structures. Graphical Abstract The latest advancements in emerging polynary bismuth-based photocatalysts over the past decade were summarized, encompassing approximately 60 species, from various aspects including crystal structure, synthesis method, modification approaches and application areas. Keywords Bi-based materials Photocatalysis Crystal structure Layered structure Photocatalytic application 1 Introduction With the advancement of industrialization and urbanization along with the continuous increase of the global population, environmental pollution and energy scarcity have emerged as two prominent societal concerns [1]. Various types of pollutants, such as organic compounds and gaseous substances including dye, antibiotics and polymer waste, pose a severe threat to the ecosystem and humans due to their high toxicity. Consequently, it's imperative to develop efficient technologies to remove and convert these pollutants. Simultaneously, the diminishing reserves of fossil fuels necessitate urgent exploration for alternative energy sources. Photocatalysis technique has been recognized as a green and environmentally friendly strategy that can settle both the above issues simultaneously [2]. In recent years, the utilization of photocatalysis has witnessed a surge in its applications across diverse domains including degradation of liquid and gaseous pollutants, water splitting for hydrogen (H2) and oxygen (O2) production, hydrogen sulfide (H2S) splitting for H2 production, carbon dioxide (CO2) reduction, nitrogen fixation (N2), hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) synthesis and organic synthesis [3–7]. Heterogeneous photocatalytic processes generally involve three steps. Firstly, the photocatalyst absorbs photon energy equal to or greater than its band gap, an electron is promoted from the valance band into the conduction band, leaving a hole. Secondly, the charge carriers separate in the bulk phase and migrate to the surface of the photocatalyst, which plays a crucial role in reactions. Thirdly, electrons and holes serve as reductants and oxidants to react with substrate molecules adsorbed on the photocatalysts surface, respectively [8]. From the perspective of photocatalysts, two main strategies can be employed to enhance photocatalytic efficiency. The first approach involves extending modifications on existing conventional photocatalysts such as TiO2, ZnO, etc., through morphology regulation, doping, internal electric field and pin-situolarization electric field control, vacancy construction, and compositing techniques [9]. The second approach focuses on exploring novel photocatalysts by synthesizing new materials specifically designed for photocatalysis or utilizing previously unexplored materials for this purpose. Given the extensive exploration of conventional photocatalysts, there is an immediate need to address the pressing challenge of developing innovative alternatives. Compared with emerging semiconducting materials of Xenes and MXenes, many Bi-based materials containing Bi3+ have been discovered to possess a narrow band gap and demonstrate remarkable photocatalytic activity due to the hybridization of O 2p and Bi 6s 2 valence bands. And the empty 6s orbital of Bi5+ makes some Bi-based materials containing Bi5+ with high visible light photocatalytic activity. Therefore, Bi-based materials have garnered significant research and investigation in terms of their synthesis, characterization and photocatalytic properties due to their diverse compositions and structures, distinctive optical and electronic properties [10–15]. From the perspective of crystal structure, they can be mainly categorized into layered Bi-based compounds and non-layered Bi-based compounds (others) [16]. Layered Bi-based compounds include Sille?n structure (such as BiOCl and Bi3O4Br), Sille?n-related structure (like Bi2O2CO3), Aurivillius structure (like Bi2MoO6 and Bi2WO6), Sille?n-Aurivillius structure (Bi4NbO8Cl). However, most reviews of Bi-based photocatalysts still primarily focus on summarizing traditional star materials, like BiVO4, Bi2WO6 and BiOX (X = Cl, Br and I) [17,18]. Numerous conventional Bi-based photocatalysts have been prepared and studied extensively. At the same time, in the last few years, an increasing number of novel Bi-based photocatalysts have emerged, like BiOIO3, Bi2O2(OH)(NO3), Bi4NbO8Br and so on [19,20]. Among these photocatalysts, photocatalytic performance can be significantly improved in materials that possess layered structures due to their thin plate-like structure and the presence of an internal static electric field perpendicular to the layers, which can significantly enhance the separation of photoinduced charge carriers [21,22]. In recent years, researchers have maintained a strong interest in developing new PBB photocatalysts due to their unique properties. Over the past decade, almost 60 types of PBB materials have been utilized as photocatalysts (Fig. 1 ). Considering the current growth in the diversity of PBB photocatalysts, it is an appropriate time to provide a comprehensive summary. Hence, we present a relatively comprehensive review on these emerging PBB photocatalysts from various perspectives including structures, modifications (structure and morphology control, construction of heterojunctions, semiconductor/metal or carbon materials heterojunctions, manipulation of internal polar electric field, introduction of oxygen vacancies or other vacancies, doping or replacement techniques and surface modification) and applications (including control of pollutants, water splitting for H2 and O2 evolution, CO2 photoreduction, N2 fixation, selective organic synthesis, H2 generation from H2S and dye sensitization), as shown in Fig. 2 . Furthermore, we discuss the relationships among structure, modification and application while also highlighting the challenges faced along with opportunities and prospects for developing PBB photocatalysts. The review aims to provide an insightful understanding on the structures and applications of emerging PBB photocatalysts and offer valuable guidelines and perspectives for fabricating exceptionally efficient photocatalysts. 2 Crystal structure of emerging PBB photocatalysts Each material possesses a distinct structural system that spans from atomic to macroscopic scales. The properties and performances of materials are reliant on their structure. Especially for semiconductor photocatalysts, subtle structural changes like doping or defects can significantly impact photoabsorption and photoelectrochemistry, thereby influencing photocatalytic activities. A comprehensive understanding of the crystal structure of semiconductor photocatalysts is crucial and advantageous for material design and modification. Based on the crystal structure, Bi-based photocatalysts are typically classified into Sille?n, Sille?n-related, Aurivillius, Sille?n-Aurivillius, perovskite and scheelite structures, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . 2.1 Sille?n-structured PBB photocatalysts The Sille?n-structured Bi-based photocatalysts constitute a significant proportion of overall Bi-based photocatalysts. These materials possess a layered structure composed of [(A,Bi)2O2] or [Bi3O4+n ] layers, along with one, two or three layers of halogen ions, such as Bi x O y Xz , ABiO2 X (A = Sr, Ca; X = Cl, Br and I) [23]. The presence of this layered structure is advantageous for the creation of active crystal facets and facilitates the separation of photoinduced charge carriers due to the internal electric field, leading to an enhancement in photocatalytic performance. However, the non-covalent bond between halogen and Bi renders the material susceptible to photocorrosion under light irradiation, thereby compromising its stability. Substituting Bi with another metal atoms with a smaller atomic radius can effectively reduce the interlayer distance of two layers, which enhances the interaction of [(A,Bi)2O2] and halogen ions and improves the stability of materials. Simultaneously, this reduction in layer spacing shortens the diffusion distance of photogenerated carriers and induces a shift in the light absorption range, ultimately leading to enhanced charge separation and light absorption efficiency. Consequently, extensive research has been conducted on the novel Sille?n-structured Bi-based materials. 2.1.1 Bi3O4Br Bi3O4Br belongs to the orthorhombic crystal system, which differs from the tetragonal structural BiOBr. The crystal structure of Bi3O4Br consists of [Bi3O4] layers and one Br layer in its repeating unit cell. The coordination environments for Bi atoms in Bi3O4Br include connections with three O atoms and two Br atoms, as well as connections with four O atoms, as shown in Fig. 4(a) . Zhang's group has confirmed that Bi3O4Br exhibits superior visible light response photocatalytic activity for sodium pentachlorophenate degradation for the first time [24]. 2.1.2 Bi4O5I2 Bi4O5I2 exhibits a monoclinic phase (space group P1211) with lattice constants of a = 1.6267 nm, b = 0.5356 nm and c = 1.1503 nm, which distinguishes it from the tetragonal phase of BiOI, as depicted in Fig. 4(b) [25–27]. Bi4O5I2 hierarchical microspheres were synthesized by Liu et al. [28] via a solvothermal method by controlling the types of alcohols and used as a photocatalyst for the first time. 2.1.3 Bi5O7Br Bi5O7Br belongs to the orthorhombic system with a space group of cmca, and its crystal parameters are a = 1.6087 nm, b = 0.52965 nm and c = 2.3022nm. The crystal structure is shown in Fig. 4(c) [29]. Each repeating cell unit contains two halogen layers in the c-axis. Chen et.al first employed Bi5O7Br as a photocatalyst to degrade the crystal violet [30]. 2.1.4 Bi12O17X2 (X = Cl, Br) Bi12O17Cl2 and Bi12O17Br2 crystallize in a tetragonal structure. The lattice constants of Bi12O17Cl2 are a = b = 0.5443 nm and c = 3.52 nm [31]. Bi12O17Cl2 and Bi12O17Br2 were used as photocatalysts for the first time by Zhang's group and Chen et al. respectively [30,32]. 2.1.5 Bi24O31X10 (X=Cl, Br) Bi24O31Cl10 and Bi24O31Br10 possess identical monoclinic structures and space group (A12/m1) [33]. The lattice constants of Bi24O31Br10 are a = 1.0002 nm, b = 0.4083 nm and c = 3.0241 nm. [Bi, O] layers are connected by shared Cl− or Br− ions, as depicted in Fig. 4(d). Nanostructured Bi24O31Cl10 was synthesized via the electrochemistry method for its application as a photocatalyst by Chen [34] in 2013. Xiao et al. [35] employed a one-step microwave heating route to synthesize Bi24O31Br10 nanoflakes for photocatalytic degradation of tetracycline hydrochlorid. 2.1.6 XBiO2Y (X=Sr, Pb, Cd, Ba; Y=Cl, Br, I) The series of Sille?n-structured materials XBiO2Y were synthesized and investigated as photocatalysts for the first time in recent years [36–38]. SrBiO2Y (Y = Cl, Br) and PbBiO2Cl crystallize in the orthorhombic system with a space group of cmca and bmmb, respectively. The distinctive layered crystal structure of SrBiO2Cl consists of alternating (SrBiO2)+ and Cl− layers along b axis (Fig. 4(f)). The neighboring layers of (SrBiO2)+ are stacked in an opposing manner to create sufficiently large cavities for accommodating Cl- ions. XBiO2Br (X = Cd, Ba) and PbBiO2I crystals exhibit a tetragonal phase with I4/mmm space group [39,40]. The lattice parameters for CdBiO2Br are determined as a = b = 0.395668 nm and c = 1.24497 nm [41]. Fig. 4(e) illustrates the crystal structure of PbBiO2I, which consists of two [PbBiO2]+ layers and two I− layers within one repeating unit cell. Chen et al. [42] reported an ultrathin layer structured Pb0.6Bi1.4O2Cl1.4 as the photocatalyst for CO2 reduction. Pb0.6Bi1.4O2Cl1.4 exhibits a tetragonal phase structure with I4/mmm space group, with an iso-structure of BiOCl, in which some Bi3+ are occupied by Pb2+. 2.1.7 LiBi3O4Cl2 and Bi2XO4Cl (X = Eu, Nd, Y) These materials belong to the Sillen-Aurivillius related structure. LiBi3O4Cl2 belongs to tetragonal I4/mmm space group and its crystal structure is composed of (LiBiO2)+ layers along with two Cl− layers, as shown in Fig. 4(g). The unit cell parameters are a = 0.384 nm, b = 0.384 nm and c = 1.203 nm. LiBi3O4Cl2 was synthesized via a solid state strategy and employed as a novel photocatalyst for dye degradation [43]. Bi2 XO4Cl (X = Eu, Nd, Y) photocatalysts are tetragonal crystal phase in the space group of P4/mmm. The crystal structure of Bi2 XO4Cl (X = Eu, Nd) is constructed by [Bi2 XO4]2+ (X = Eu, Nd and Y) layers and one Cl− layer, as depicted in Fig. 4(h) [43–45]. 2.1.8 Bi2O2X (X = S, Se) Bi2O2 X (X = S, Se) are relatively novel materials that belong to the bismuth oxychalcogenide family (S: Pnnm, Se: I4/mmm space group) [46]. They possess a layered structure consisting of tetragonal [Bi2O2]2+ layers with S/Se present in the inter-layer position, similar to that of BiOX, as shown in Fig. 4(i) [47]. Due to the low effective mass, Bi2O2X shows extremely high carrier mobility (about 30000 cm2 V−1 at 1.9 K) [48]. Additionally, S or Se atoms between the [Bi2O2]2+ layers narrow the band gap (~1.34 eV for Bi2O2S and ~1.19 eV for Bi2O2Se) and enhance the bond energy compared with halogen ions, enabling the materials to exhibit an excellent photo-response and maintain excellent stability during photocatalytic reactions. 2.2 Sille?n-related structured PBB photocatalysts The Sille?n-related structure is distinguished from the traditional Sille?n structure by its layered composition of [Bi2O2]2+ and acid group anions, showcasing a distinctive feature in terms of its structural arrangement. For example, the crystal structure of Bi2O2CO3 comprises alternating layers of [Bi2O2]2+ and [CO3]2− ions. Due to the combined effects of hybridized energy bands and layered architecture, there is significant importance and interest in developing Sille?n-related structured materials for various photocatalytic applications. 2.2.1 BiOIO3 BiOIO3 was investigated as a layered Bi-based photocatalyst in 2013 [49,50]. The stereochemically active lone pairs on both Bi3+ and I5+ are situated at hexagonal BiO6 sites and trigonal pyramidal IO3 sites, respectively. So BiOIO3 contains polar IO3 anionic groups and a (Bi2O2)2+ layer. It crystallizes in the orthorhombic phase with a Pca21 space group, characterized by unit cell parameters of a = 0.56584 nm, b = 1.10386 nm and c = 0.57476 nm. Additionally, due to the presence of IO3 pyramids, BiOIO3 exhibits pyroelectric properties. As depicted in Fig. 5(a) , local dipole moments exist within the IO3 pyramids but not within the BiO6 pyramids, resulting in a pyroelectric polarization along the c-axis direction. Consequently, electrons and holes can migrate in opposite directions under the polarization of the electric field. 2.2.2 Bi2O2[BO2(OH)] and Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) and Bi2O2[BO2(OH)] were demonstrated as intriguing photocatalysts for the degradation of industrial pollutants and antibiotics by our group [51,52]. Bi2O2[BO2(OH)] belongs to the monoclinic crystal phase with a space group of Cm. The unit cell parameters are a = 0.54676 nm, b = 1.46643 nm, c = 0.39058 nm, and β = 135.59o. The structure of Bi2O2[BO2(OH)] consists of [Bi2O2]2+ and [BO3]3− layers, as shown in Fig. 5(b). There is only one coordination environment of Bi atom in Bi2O2[BO2(OH)], which connects with one B atom, and three O atoms through Bi−O bonds. This structure bears resemblance to that of Bi2O2CO3, which were constructed by (Bi2O2)2+ and (CO3)2− layers. Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) crystallizes in an orthorhombic phase with a space group of Cmc21. Its crystal parameters are a = 0.53878 nm, b = 0.53984 nm and c = 1.7136 nm. The structure of Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) comprises [Bi2O2]2+ layers interleaved with [NO3] groups along with OH along the c-axis, as shown in Fig. 5(c). There are two coordination environments of Bi atoms in its structure which connect with four or five O atoms to form BiO4 and BiO5 (Bi−O bond length ranging between 0.2226 and 0.2341 nm). 2.3 Aurivillius-structured PBB photocatalysts The Aurivillius-structured materials can be described by the general formula (Bi2O2)2+(A n−1B n O3n+1)2−, where n represents the number of octahedral layers. These materials consist of a pseudo-peroskite [A n−1B n O3n+1]2− pseudo perovskite layer inserted between (Bi2O2)2+ layers along the c-axis. Hence, the photocatalytic performance of Aurivillius-structured materials largely depends on [A n−1B n O3n+1]2− pseudo perovskite layer and [Bi2O2]2+ layer. In recent years, many Aurivillius-structured photocatalysts such as Bi2MoO6, Bi2WO6, PbBi2Nb2O9 and Bi3TiNbO9 have attracted much interest due to their superior photocatalytic activities. 2.3.1 CdBi2Nb2O9 The crystal structure of CdBi2Nb2O9 belongs to the orthorhombic phase in P212121 space group with unit cell parameters a = 1.8221 nm, b = 0.3748 nm and c = 0.3239 nm. CdBi2Nb2O9 nanospheres were initially reported by Kulkarni et al. [53] as a photocatalyst for H2 generation from H2S under visible light irradiation. 2.3.2 Bi2XO5F(X=Nb, Ta) Bi2 XO5F (X = Nb, Ta) were prepared via a low temperature solution method and firstly used as photocatalysts for degradation of MO and RhB [54]. The crystal structure of Bi2 XO5F (X = Nb, Ta) belongs to a body-centered tetragonal structure with space group of I4/mmm. [Nb(OF)6] and [Bi2(OF)2] layers alternate with each other along c-axis, as illustrated in Fig. 6(a) . F atom can effectively enhance the separation of photoinduced electron-hole pairs owing to its strong electronegativity, therefore improving photocatalytic performance. It is proved that they are ferroelectric semiconductors with a relatively narrow indirect band gap (2.86 eV for Bi2NbO5F and 2.95 eV for Bi2TaO5F). 2.3.3 SrBi4Ti4O15 SrBi4Ti4O15 possesses a polar non-centrosymmetric structure with the space group of A21am, which was initially reported as a photocatalyst for CO2 reduction by our group [55]. The crystal structure of SrBi4Ti4O15 consists of [Bi2O2]2+ layers, with four layer TiO6 octahedra interleaved alternatively along the c axis (Fig. 6(b)). Within the cavities of the TiO6 octahedra, both Sr and Bi atoms co-occupy the central site, resulting in spontaneous polarization due to an asymmetrical charge center. 2.3.4 Pb2Bi4Ti5O18 The Pb2Bi4Ti5O18 crystal exhibits an orthorhombic structure in Aba2 space group, characterized by lattice constants of a = 0.54700 nm, b = 0.54575 nm and c = 4.96434 nm. It consists of [Bi2O2]2+ layers and five layer TiO6 octahedra along c axis. The central site in TiO6 octahedra is occupied by Pb and Bi atoms (Fig. 6(c)) [56]. 2.3.5 Bi2CrO6 Bi2CrO6 exhibits an orthorhombic structure in the Pca2 space group, comprising layers of (Bi2O2)2+ and MO4 octahedra oriented along the c-axis. The band gap of Bi2CrO6 is approximately 2.00 eV, enabling it to effectively respond to visible light [57]. 2.4 Sille?n-Aurivillius structured PBB photocatalysts Recently, the Sillén-Aurivillius hybrid perovskites composed of Sillén and Aurivillius structures have been investigated as highly efficient photocatalysts with excellent visible light response. These photocatalysts have a general formula of (BiO2)2X(A n–1M n O3n+1), consisting of [Bi2O2]2+ layers, [A x O y ] layers and halide layers along the c-axis. The unique layered structure is believed to facilitate effective charge carrier separation. Recently, Bi4NbO8Cl (n = 1) was discovered as a stable oxygen evolution photocatalyst under visible light, further driving research towards synthesizing other Sillén­Aurivillius photocatalysts. 2.4.1 Bi4NbO8Br, Bi4X (X=V, Sb, Ti0.5W0.5)O8Cl Bi4NbO8Br, which is similar to Bi4NbO8Cl, was successfully prepared through a solid state reaction method by our group and employed as a photocatalyst for the first time [58]. Bi4NbO8Br adopts an orthorhombic structure in P21cn space group and possesses a layered arrangement consists of [Bi2O2]2+, [NbO4]3− and Br− layers. As depicted in Figs. 7(a) and (b) , the perovskite block [NbO4] is formed by connecting adjacent NbO6 octahedras via shared corners. The unique layered structure is formed by stacking alternating layers of [Bi2O2], [NbO4], [Bi2O2] and [Br] along the c-axis. Pandey et al. [59] synthesized La-substituted Bi3LaNbO8 X (X = Cl, Br) via solid state reaction. Bi3LaNbO8 X (X = Cl, Br) can be indexed in the P21cn space group. Additionally, Bi4 X (X = V, Sb, Ti0.5W0.5)O8Cl photocatalysts have the same structure and similar band gaps with Bi4NbO8Br (2.36 eV for Bi4VO8Cl, 2.53 eV for Bi4SbO8Cl and 2.36 eV for Bi4Ti0.5W0.5O8Cl) [30]. 2.4.2 Bi5X(X=Sr, Pb)Ti3O14Cl Bi5 X (X = Sr, Pb)Ti3O14Cl exhibits a non-centrosymmetric space group of P2an. Ryu Abe's group explored fourteen compounds with n = 2 phases AA′Bi3M2O11Cl (A, A′ = Sr, Ba, Pb, Bi; M = Ti, Nb, Ta), and initially reported the Sillén-Aurivillius oxychloride of Bi5 X (X = Sr, Pb)Ti3O14Cl (n = 3) for photocatalytic water splitting. As depicted in Figs. 7(c) and (d), Pb atoms replace the Bi site in the crystal structure [60]. It was observed that as the value of n increases, there is a greater contribution from Sr and Pb 6s hybridized with O 2p compared to Bi 6s with O 2p in VBM. Additionally, they also documented a series of Ba x Bi5Ti y O z Cl materials (BaBi5Ti3O14Cl, Ba2Bi5Ti4O17Cl and Ba3Bi5Ti5O20Cl) which possess triple, quadruple and quintuple-perovskite layers for photocatalytic water splitting [61]. The structures of these three materials were built by BaTiO3 perovskite, Sillén-phase BaBiO2Cl and Aurivillius-phase Bi4Ti3O12, BaBi4Ti4O15, or Ba2Bi4Ti5O18. They demonstrated that the photocatalytic activity is enhanced by augmenting the n number of perovskite layers. 2.4.3 Bi6NbWO14Cl The intergrowth compound Bi6NbWO14Cl was initially investigated by Kunioku et al. [62] for its photocatalytic O2-evolving under visible light. Bi6NbWO14Cl belongs to the orthorhombic structure in Fmmm space group with unit cell parameters of a = 0.547826 nm, b = 0.544114 nm, c = 4.52874 nm. Bi6NbWO14Cl exhibits an intergrowth structure, consisting of an Aurivillius unit Bi2O2(Nb,W)O4 and a Sillén­Aurivillius unit [(Bi2O2)2Cl](Nb,W)O4. Essentially, it is composed of [(Nb0.5W0.5)O4]2.5– perovskite layers, [(Bi2O2)2Cl]3+ and [Bi2O2]2+ layers with a sandwiched structure. 2.5 Other PBB photocatalysts 2.5.1 Bi(IO3)3 and BiCuSeO Bi(IO3)3 was employed as a photocatalyst for the degradation of organic pollutants by our group for the first time [49]. The crystal structure of Bi(IO3)3 belongs to the monoclinic phase in space group of P2/n with unit cell constants of a = 0.88882 nm, b = 0.59445 nm and c = 1.52445 nm. As shown in Fig. 8(a) , the structure of Bi(IO3)3 consists of Bi−O polyhedrons and IO3 anions. The existence of a lone pair electron within IO3 − group makes it polar. BiCuSeO is characterized by a layered arrangement structure with the tetragonal P4/nmm space group, wherein insulating layers of (Bi2O2)2+ and conductive layers of (Cu2Se2)2− are stacked alternately along the c-axis [63]. 2.5.2 Bi2X4O9(X=Ga, Al) and Bi2(CrO4)3 The structures of Bi2 X (X = Ga, Al)4O9 are mullite phase in Pbam space group [64]. As shown in Fig. 8(b), Ga2O7 (corner-shared GaO4 tetrahedra) cross links GaO6 − chains to form a 3D structure that creates large cavities for Bi3+. Yang et al. [65] developed Bi2Ga4O9 as a novel Bi-based photocatalyst for overall water splitting. Bi2(CrO4)3 possesses a monoclinic structure in P21/c space group and has been reported as a photocatalyst with a direct band gap of 2.45 eV for hydrogen production [66]. 2.5.3 Bi4B2O9, Bi4MoO9 In previous works, Bi4B2O9 has been utilized as ceramic due to its excellent dielectric properties [67]. Our group investigates the photoelectrochemical properties, and photocatalytic activity of Bi4B2O9 for the first time [52]. The structure of Bi4B2O9 belongs to the monoclinic phase in P2/c space group with the lattice constants of a = 1.1127 nm, b = 0.6641 nm, c = 1.1058 nm, and β = 90.91°. As depicted in Fig. 8(c), Bi4B2O9 consists of BO3 triangles, BiO4 tetrahedron, and BiO5 polyhedra. There are two coordination environments of Bi atoms, one involves two Bi atoms forming a BiO4 tetrahedron while the other comprises two constituting BiO5 polyhedra to interconnect with each other, resulting in the formation of a Bi2O2 chain. Bi4MoO9 is a face-centered cubic phase (a = b = c = 0.5645 nm) with a wide band gap of 3.39 eV [48,68]. Notably, this material exhibits remarkable photooxidation ability attributed to its positive valance band position. 2.5.4 Bi6X2O15 (X=Mo, S, Cr) Bi6Mo2O15 was first reported as a photocatalyst by Zou et al. [274]. Bi6Mo2O15 belongs to monoclinic phase with space group of P2/c and unit cell parameters of a = 2.4786 nm, b = 0.5805 nm, c = 2.3527 nm, α = γ = 90°, β = 102.93°. Despite Cr and Mo belong to the same VIB group, the crystal structures of Bi6Mo2O15 and Bi6Cr2O15 are completely different, and Bi6Cr2O15 has an orthorhombic structure in Ccc2 space group with a narrowed band gap of 1.95 eV [69]. Zhu's group first reported the photocatalytic properties of Bi6S2O15 which also has an orthorhombic structure in Ccc2 space group similar to that of Bi6Cr2O15 [70]. Additionally, the unit cell for [Bi12O14] n 8n+ stretches along the c-axis with eight SO4 2− tetrahedra surrounding it. Bi6S2O15 exhibits a wide band gap of approximately 3.35 eV. 2.5.5 Bi8(CrO4)O11 Bi8(CrO4)O11 photocatalyst, with a wide spectrum responsive (approximately 678 nm), was constructed and first reported by Zhu et al. [20]. The crystal structure of Bi8(CrO4)O11 belongs to monoclinic space group P21/m, with lattice constants of a = 0.9657 nm, b = 1.1934 nm, c = 1.3868 nm and β = 104.14°. It is stacked by slabs of (CrO4)2− tetrahedral units and Bi polyhedral (Bi3+ coordinated by 5−8 oxygen atoms) along the a-axis [71]. 2.5.6 Bi12XO20 (X = Mn, Ge) Bi12MnO20 and Bi12GeO20 materials were initially identified as photocatalysts by Zhang et al. [72] and Dong et al. [73], respectively. The two materials possess the same cubic sillenite structure in I23 space group. As shown in Fig. 8(d), Bi12MnO20 consists of corner sharing MnO4 tetrahedrons and BiO7 polyhedrons. The MnO4 tetrahedrons are formed by nine Mn4+ ions located at the body center and corners of the unit cell, while BiO7 polyhedrons are composed of Bi3+ ions coordinated by seven O atoms. A dipole moment parallel to the lone pair of Bi3+ 6s 2 in BiO7 polyhedron facilitates the separation of photogenerated charge carriers. However, the same crystal structure of the two photocatalysts exhibit significant differences in their band structures, with a band gap of 1.86 eV for Bi12MnO20 and 2.80 eV for Bi12GeO20. 2.5.7 Bi14XO24(X=Mo, Cr) Bi14MoO24 possesses a tetragonal crystal structure in I4/m space group, characterized by unit cell constants of a = 0.86932 nm, c = 1.72894 nm and α = 90°. There are three types of Bi−O polyhedral in Bi14MoO24, where Bi(1) site forms a distorted trigonal prism by connecting with two O atoms, Bi(2) introduces a square pyramid by concatenating two adjacent and one opposite O atoms, and Bi(3) coordinates with eight O atoms [68]. Compared to the structure of Bi2O3, the more spacious arrangement in Bi14MoO24 may contribute to the higher separation of photogenerated electron-hole pairs and enhanced photocatalytic performance. The band gap of Bi14MoO24 is approximately 2.91 eV [74]. With a similar structure, Bi14CrO24 has been reported to exhibit photocatalytic activity towards organic dye decomposition [75]. 2.5.8 K2Bi(PO4)(MoO4), Na3Bi(PO4)2, Na3Bi2(PO4)3, XBi2B2O7(X=Ca, Sr), ZnBi2O4 and Cr2Bi3O11 K2Bi(PO4)(MoO4), which was explored as a photocatalyst by our group in 2014 [76]. It crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal phase in Ibca space group (unit cell parameters: a = 1.97037 nm, b = 1.24752 nm, c = 0.70261 nm) (Fig. 8(e)) [77]. Our group also investigated the photocatalytic performance of Na3Bi2(PO4)3 and Na3Bi(PO4)2 [78]. Na3Bi2(PO4)3 crystallizes in a hexagonal phase with P63/m space group, while Na3Bi(PO4)2 is a monoclinic phase with P2/c space group. As depicted in Figs. 8(f) and (g), both structures consist of PO4 tetrahedra and BiO n polyhedra. Specifically, Na3Bi2(PO4)3 contains BiO9 polyhedra, whereas Na3Bi(PO4)2 comprises BiO8 polyhedra. CaBi2B2O7 exhibits an orthorhombic phase in Pna21 space group and consists of layers arranged with CaO6 trigonal prisms and BO3 triangles that share corners. The photocatalytic performance of CaBi2B2O7 was first reported by our group in 2020 [79]. Sr atom belongs to the same chemical family as Ca atom; however, SrBi2B2O7 possesses a different crystal structure from that of CaBi2B2O7, which has a hexagonal P63 space group [80]. ZnBi2O4 belongs to the spinel structure family and shares similarities with the crystal structure of CuBi2O4. Zhang et al. [81] employed ZnBi2O4 as a photocatalyst for the degradation of brilliant red K-2G and acid red B in 2015. For the first time, Cr2Bi3O11 was explored as a photocatalyst by Meng et al. [48]. It has a crystal structure constructed alternately by [CrO4] and [Bi2O2] layers in a-, b- and c-axis and a narrow band gap of approximately 2.2 eV with superb photoadsorption. 2.5.9 Bi(C2O4)OH Bi-based hydroxyl oxalate, Bi(C2O4)OH, belongs to the orthorhombic phase in the space group of Pnma, with crystal parameters a = 0.60853 nm, b = 1.14479 nm and c = 0.59722 nm. The crystal structure of Bi(C2O4)OH consists of BiO6 polyhetra and [C2O4] groups which are connected via two bridging O atoms along b-axis (Fig. 8(h)). It was successfully synthesized using a precipitation strategy, and the photocatalytic activities were investigated for the first time by our group. [82] 2.9.10 Bi2O(OH)2SO4 and Bi3O(OH)(PO4)2 Tian et al. [83] first reported the photocatalyst Bi2O(OH)2SO4, which belongs to the monoclinic phase with P21/c space group. The crystal parameters are a = 0.7692 nm, b = 1.387 nm, c = 0.5688 nm and β = 109.01°. It is composed of SO4 2− group and [Bi2O(OH)2 2+] n double chains (Fig. 8(i)). The [Bi2O(OH)2 2+] n double chains involves Bi(1)-OH(1)-Bi(2)-O and Bi(1)-OH(2)-Bi(2)-O-Bi(1)-O, where two Bi atoms are connected by each OH group and each O atom connects three Bi atoms. The redundant O atoms of SO4 2− group form coordination spheres between Bi(1) and Bi(2). Known as Petitjeanite in mineralogy, the crystal structure of Bi3O(OH)(PO4)2 is a triclinic phase with P1? space group [84]. 2.9.11 Bi6O5(OH)3(NO3)5·3H2O, Bi6O6(OH)3(NO3)3·1.5H2O, Bi6O6(OH)2(NO3)4·2H2O and Bi6O4(OH)4(NO3)6·4H2O A series of basic nitrates with the general molecular formula of [Bi6O4+x (OH)4−x (NO3)6−x ·nH2O, x = 0–2; n = 0–3] have been developed as photocatalysts. Bi6O5(OH)3(NO3)5·3H2O synthesized via a direct hydrolysis process was employed for photocatalysis first by our group [85]. The structure of Bi6O5(OH)3(NO3)5·3H2O is monoclinic phase in P21/c space group, with parameters of a = 1.7152 nm, b = 0.9181 nm, c = 1.7752 nm. As shown in Fig. 8(j), Bi6O5(OH)3(NO3)5·3H2O consists of polycations wherein the [Bi6O5(OH)3] group connects to two bridging O atoms along with NO3 − and H2O. By using the hydrothermal method, Bi6O6(OH)3(NO3)3·1.5H2O photocatalyst was synthesized, which possesses a tetragonal structure with cell parameters a = b = 0.3818 nm and c = 1.7149 nm [86]. Both Bi6O6(OH)2(NO3)4·2H2O and Bi6O4(OH)4(NO3)6·4H2O exhibit monoclinic phase in P21/c space group with lattice constants of a = 0.9059 nm, b = 1.705 nm, c = 1.8269 nm and β = 120° [87,88]. 3 Synthesis methods of emerging PBB photocatalysts 3.1 Hydrothermal/solvothermal method Table 1 presents the structure type, space group and synthesis methods of emerging PBB photocatalysts. Typically, most of these materials can not be prepared under mild conditions like hydrolysis at room temperature. Hydrothermal/solvothermal methods are the most commonly employed strategy for synthesizing PBB photocatalysts [89]. In comparison to the sol-gel method and solid state method, the hydrothermal/solvothermal approach offers advantages in terms of preventing particle agglomeration, and impurities caused by grinding and high temperature sintering. The relatively low temperature and pressure in the hydrothermal/solvothermal route are conducive to producing crystals with few defects and well-defined orientation [90]. By modulating factors such as solvent type, organic additives, temperature, pH value and reaction time during the process of synthesis, it's possible to regulate the purity, morphology, crystal size and facet, thickness, doping levels as well as vacancies within photocatalysts. 3.2 Solid state reaction method The solid-state reaction method is a conventional and straightforward approach to the preparation of powdery photocatalysts. It offers advantages such as simplicity, rapidity and high yield in the preparation process. However, it also suffers from drawbacks including high energy consumption, low efficiency and impurity issues. Some Aurivillius structured and Sillén-Aurivillius structured NPBB photocatalysts require high temperature to synthesize pure crystal. Moreover, higher synthesis temperatures lead to better crystallization. Bi6NbWO14Cl belongs to Sillén-Aurivillius structure, which can be prepared via a solid-state method by heating the mixture of Bi2O3, BiOCl, Nb2O5 and WO3 at 800 °C for 20 h [62]. The molten salt method has been demonstrated as an effective approach to lower the calcination temperature and tailor the morphologies by alternating different compositions or ratios of salts and reaction temperature and time. Hailili et al. [56] utilized different compositions of salt (a mixture of KCl, NaCl, Na2SO4, and NaH2PO4) to synthesize Pb2Bi4Ti5O18 with various morphologies at 900 °C for 2 h. They found the initial step in the molten salt method is the ionization of the salt solvent when it reaches its melting point. The ions formed in molten reactions play a crucial role in determining the morphologies of materials. By utilizing Cl− and H2PO4 − ions, they successfully synthesized Pb2Bi4Ti5O18 nanoplates, taking advantage of these two ions’ high affinity for absorption on the edges, corners, or specific index surfaces of Pb2Bi4Ti5O18. Additionally, well-crystallined Bi4NbO8Br nanoplates were synthesized at 750 °C for 4 h by using a mixture of NaCl and KCl as molten salts [19]. The solid state method, which consumes a significant amount of energy, has prompted the development of various alternative approaches for synthesizing high purity materials. 3.3 Other methods Except for the hydrothermal/solvothermal method and solid state reaction method, there are several other methods available for synthesizing PBB, including microwave heating, hydrolysis, sol-gel and self-assembly methods. The microwave heating method utilizes the interaction of molecules with an electromagnetic field to transfer energy rather than conventional heat transfer. This approach presents distinctive benefits including swift heating, accelerated kinetics, and a homogeneous environment for crystal growth nucleation. By employing the microwave heating method, hierarchically structured oxygen-rich Bi4O5I2 with thin nanosheets and uniform morphology was successfully prepared [91]. This material exhibited enhanced photocatalytic phenol degradation activity attributed to its stronger internal electric field and increased surface active sites. The hydrolysis method is deemed a cost-effective approach that operates under low temperature conditions. However, it often results in poor crystallization of photocatalysts due to the fast preparation process and low temperature. [Bi6O6(OH)2](NO3)4·2H2O with different morphology were prepared by hydrolysis Bi(NO3)3 with adjusting of urea amounts in 2ME solution [92]. The sol-gel method is another promising technique for preparing photocatalyst films at low reaction temperatures while ensuring material uniformity. Nevertheless, this approach typically requires a long reaction time and involves expensive or toxic raw materials. Sillenite-type Bi12MnO20 was prepared using a facile sol-gel method followed by calcination [72]. It demonstrated excellent performance in photocatalytic degradation of acid red G. The self-assembly strategy is rapid and easily implementable. Ye's group initially synthesized Bi5O7Br nanotubes using a low-temperature self-assembly method assisted by oleyamine and water [93]. By adjusting the amount of water and stirring time, the morphology of Bi5O7Br transformed from nanosheets to ultrafine nanotubes. Ultra-thin Bi5O7Br nanotubes with abundant oxygen vacancies exhibited excellent photocatalytic N2 fixation performance. In summary, apart from hydrothermal/solvothermal and solid state reactions, alternative methods may prove effective in synthesizing uniquely structured materials due to the complexity of the synthesis process. 4 Modifications of emerging PBB photocatalysts 4.1 Morphology control and active facet exposing Constructing 3D hierarchical or hollow structures represents an effective approach to achieve superior photocatalytic activities, primarily due to the enhanced surface area and photoabsorption capabilities. Hollow microspheres Bi24O31Cl10 was prepared by heating at 600 °C with carbonaceous microsphere sacrificial templates, as illustrated in Fig. 9(a) [127]. It exhibited remarkable visible light photocatalytic degradation activity towards RhB. The exceptional performance can be attributed to the efficient photosensitization process, effective charge separation, and the presence of a hollow structure that significantly enhances photoabsorption. The concentration of the reaction precursors is adjusted to synthesize hollow Bi4O5I2 microspheres, which exhibit a high specific surface area and exceptional visible light photocatalytic performance in the degradation of RhB (Fig. 9(b)) [128]. Bi3O4Br nanorings were fabricated using a facile solvothermal method (Fig. 9(c)) [103]. The formation of precursors, selective etching and ostwald ripening constitute the key steps in achieving the ring-like morphology. Importantly, this synthesis approach eliminates the need for additional templates. Remarkably, the Bi3O4Br nanorings exhibit superior performance in terms of oxygen-evolution and pollutant degradation. Bi24O31Br10 with a grain-like hierarchical architecture was obtained by incorporating starch (Fig. 9(d)) [100]. Han et al. [107] synthesized flower-like Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) with a high surface area and excellent photodegradation activities for RhB and crystal violet (Fig. 9(e)). Unique hemispherical Bi12O17Br2, which was synthesized by the assistant of CTAB in urea solution, exhibited excellent visible light photocatalytic degradation of RhB (Fig. 9(f)) [95]. PbBiO2Cl with a truncated bipyramid nanostructure exposing {002} and {103} facets was prepared to degrade 4-chlorophenol under visible irradiation and demonstrated superior photocatalytic performance compared to BiOCl. The formation mechanism of a unique truncated bipyramid structure is based on minimum energy principle during the reaction between Pb2+ and BiOCl layers to form PbBiO2Cl [36]. 2D nanosheet structured photocatalysts with specific facet also exhibit excellent performance due to the unique atom arrangement on the surface. Brick-like Bi2O2S was prepared via a facile hydrothermal method with the addition of LiOH·H2O as an additive (Fig. 9(g)) [90]. Bi24O31Br10 nanosheets were prepared and their photocatalytic performance was researched by degradation of tetracycline hydrochloride [101]. Furthermore, the enhanced photocatalytic performance can be attributed to a decrease in thickness, which affects band structure, charge carrier density, as well as transfer and separation of charge carriers. These findings highlight that smaller-sized nanosheets exhibit superior performance due to their ultrathin structure. Ultrasmall Bi4O5I2 nanosheets with few-layers were synthesized using an ionic liquid [Hmim]I-mannitol assisted solvothermal method by Xia's group, where the pH was adjusted [102]. In this synthesis process, the ionic liquid acted as a solvent, capping agent and source of I, resulting in six-layered Bi4O5I2. 2D ultrathin photocatalyts often exhibit high activities due to the exposure of abundant coordination unsaturated sites, while the short migration distance of photogenerated electrons and holes can effectively enhance the separation efficiency of charge carriers. Ultrathin Pb0.6Bi1.4O2Cl1.4 was synthesized via a top-down desalination strategy from Pb0.6Bi1.4Cs0.6O2Cl2 [42]. This proposed method could effectively weaken the ionic bonded between Cs−Cl interlayer present in Pb0.6Bi1.4Cs0.6O2Cl2, due to the more significant water dissolution of Cs−Cl than Pb−Cl, Bi−Cl, Bi−O and Pb−O bonds. The prepared Pb0.6Bi1.4O2Cl1.4 demonstrated a significantly enhanced specific surface area with well-defined Bi catalytic centers, thereby exhibiting exceptional performance in CO2 reduction. The microrods, nanorods, nanowires and straw sheaves like Bi(C2O4)OH were synthesized by Zhu's group via the hydrothermal method (Fig. 9(h)). They prepared these structures by precisely controlling the oxalate source, EG/H2O volumetric ratio, H2C2O4/Bi(NO3)3 molar ratio, temperature and reaction time [126]. Bi5O7Br ultrafine nanotube, with an average diameter of 5 nm, was prepared via a water-assisted self-assembly method at low temperature using oleylamine and water as crucial additives (Fig. 9(i)) [93]. This synthesis process involved two steps: firstly, the complexation of Bi3+ and Br− with oleylamine; subsequently, the hydrolysis and self-assembly of the complex into ultrathin nanotubes. This unique ultrafine nanotube Bi5O7Br exhibited excellent photocatalytic N2 fixation activity under visible light. The exposed facets of photocatalysts play a crucial role in the photocatalytic process. It has been confirmed that reactive facets possess high photooxidation ability. Our group synthesized Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) with exposed {001} active facets (as shown in Figs. 10(a)–(e) ) by one-step hydrothermal strategy [51]. In this reaction, strong active radicals are generated due to the presence of {001} active facets, enabling Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) to demonstrate robust and long lasting photooxidation ability. Bi2Ga4O9 nanoplates with {110} facets were prepared via the hydrothermal method [116]. The results of electrochemical and photocatalytic performances disclose that Bi2Ga4O9 nanoplates with high-reactive {110} facets demonstrated higher activity for Acid Red 1 azo dye removal compared to Bi2Ga4O9 particles. Hierarchical hollow spheres of Bi3O4Br assembled with {001}-active facets were prepared by an ionic liquid-in-water microemulsion method [129]. Bi3O4Br with {001} active facets exhibited efficient promotion of visible light nonselective photooxidation ability for multiform phenol derivatives. Highly reactive {010} facets of BiOIO3 also demonstrated excellent photocatalytic Hg0 removal ability [130]. In general, morphology and active facet control are very important for the enhancement of photocatalytic activities. The fabrication of 3D hierarchical structures such as flower-like, hollow spheres exhibits superior photocatalytic performance compared to bulk materials. The presence of these 3D structures facilitates enhanced photo absorption through multiple reflections and scatterings of light, and improves the specific surface area. 2D layered structure is advantageous due to their unique nanosheet morphology, which leads to an increased surface area. Consequently, this structure facilitates the availability of abundant reactive sites for photoredox reactions. 1D structures exhibit the advantages of unique longitudinal directional migration of charge carriers, large specific surface area with highly exposed active sites, and enhanced photoabsorption. However, the synthesis of 1D structures for emerging PBB photocatalysts possesses challenges due to their layered crystal structure. The photocatalytic process is significantly influenced by exposed facets of photocatalysts due to the different surface atom coordination. It has been experimentally verified that reactive facets exhibit exceptional photoredox abilities owing to the presence of active sites, which facilitate the adsorption and activation of substrate reaction molecules. The manipulation of the exposed facet of emerging materials offers a promising approach to regulate the arrangement of distinct specific surface atoms, thereby controlling both photocatalytic activity and selectivity. 4.2 Construction of junctions Construction of junctions is a conventional and effective strategy for modifying photocatalysts, which mainly include Z-scheme heterojunction, p-n heterojunction, ternary heterojunction, conventional binary heterojunction and facet homojunction. Z-scheme heterojunctions represent a unique type of junction that enhances the separation of photogenerated charge carriers by facilitating the transfer of photoexcited electrons from the more positive CB of one photocatalyst to the more negative VB of another photocatalyst, thereby promoting recombination with the holes under light irradiation. However, fabricating such heterojunctions remains challenging. Z-scheme heterojunction of Bi2O2(OH)(NO3)-BiPO4 was fabricated by Liu et al. [131]. This Z-scheme heterojunction exhibits excellent photodegradation performance for 2,4-DCP under UV light irradiation. The ESR signals of ·OH-DMPO were used to examine the Z-scheme mechanism. Compared with pure Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) and BiPO4, the heterojunction shows the highest ·OH-DMPO signal, indicating enhanced photocatalytic activity of heterojunctions. Since the redox potential of ·OH for OH−/·OH is 2.8 eV, which is higher than the VB position of Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) (2.63 eV), further confirming the presence of Z-scheme heterojunction. BiOIO3/g-C3N4 Z-scheme heterostructures were fabricated and displayed remarkable photocatalytic performance for the degradation of MO, RhB, 2,4-DCP or oxidation of gaseous Hg0 [132,133]. In this system, I3 −/I− redox pairs form at the interface of heterojunction and act as electron mediators that promote charge separation [134]. The analysis of CB and VB positions confirms the Z-scheme mechanism between BiOIO3 and g-C3N4. The Z-scheme nanostructure showed enhanced charge separation efficiency and improved stability during the reaction process. In Bi4O5I2/AgI Z-scheme composite, both ·OH and ·O2 − were detected participating in TC degradation and E. coli inactivation (Fig. 11(a) ) [135]. Constructing p-n heterojunction is an alternative and efficient strategy for enhancing the separation of photoinduced charge carriers. In this process, the photoexcited holes move from VB of n-type semiconductor to the VB of p-type semiconductor, while the photoexcited electrons transfer from the CB of p-type semiconductor to the CB of n-type semiconductor. Our group develops a Bi12O17Cl2/BiOI p-n heterojunction by facile in-situ vertical assembly of highly exposed {001} reactive facet BiOI nanosheets on Bi12O17Cl2 plates through charge induction [136]. This p-n heterojunction exhibited significantly enhanced visible light photodegradation properties of 2,4-DCP, phenol, BPA, RhB and tetracycline hydrochloride. The enhanced segregation and transportation of photoinduced charge carriers can be ascribed to the combination of a p-n junction and active {001} facets in BiOI, which was confirmed by photoelectrochemical results. The possible process of charge separation for n-Bi12O17Cl2/p-BiOI composite in the system is shown in Fig. 11(b). Additionally, our group also fabricated an n-BiOIO3-(010)/p-BiOI heterojunction by using thiourea as a reducing agent via an in-situ reduction method which showed enhanced photo activity for MB degradation [137]. p-BiOBr/n-Bi(C2O4)OH heterojunction was successfully prepared via chemical etching by Liu et al. [138], showing commendable photocatalytic activity for the degradation of RhB under visible light. Furthermore, p-BiOCl/n-PbBiO2Cl also exhibited excellent photocatalytic degradation performance for crystal violet [139]. The p-n-p heterojunction of BiOI/Bi4O5I2/Bi2O2CO3 photocatalyst was prepared by Peng et al. [140] via a low-temperature solution strategy, employing Bi2O3 nanorods as sacrificial templates. In comparison to pure Bi2O2CO3, BiOI and Bi4O5I2, this p-n-p ternary heterojunction demonstrated exceptional efficiency in the photodegradation of RhB and MB under solar light irradiation. This improvement in photocatalytic performance can be attributed to the efficient separation of photoinduced charge carriers. The photogenerated electrons from BiOI and Bi4O5I2 migrate to the CB of Bi2O2CO3 while the holes from Bi2O2CO3 transfer to the VB of both BiOI and Bi4O5I2, thereby enhancing the charge separation within the system. The construction of ternary heterojunctions can facilitate charge separation more effectively. Zhu's group prepared a ternary heterojunction of Bi4O5Br2/Bi24O31Br10/Bi2SiO5 through an in-situ ion exchange reaction [141]. This ternary heterojunction exhibited superior performance in the photodegradation of phenol under visible light. The well-matched band structures of the three materials improved the separation of charge carriers, resulting in a notable improvement in photocatalytic performance. Ternary Ag/AgBr/BiOIO3 photocatalysts were prepared via in-situ crystallization of Ag/AgBr on BiOIO3 by our group [142]. The composite demonstrated excellent photocatalytic decomposition capabilities for various phenols and antibiotics, benefiting from the synergistic effect between heterojunction and surface plasmon resonance (SPR) effect of metallic Ag. PbBiO2I/Bi5O7I/g-C3N4 ternary heterojunction was also developed to achieve cascade charge transfer and enhance charge separation during the photocatalytic process (Fig. 11(c)) [143]. Other ternary heterostructured photocatalysts like g-C3N4/Bi12O17Br2/Bi2O3, BiOBr/Bi24O31Br10/TiO2, Ag/AgCl/BiOIO3, carbon spheres/BiOI/BiOIO3, BiOCl/ Bi24O31Cl10/RGO, BiOCl/Bi12O17Cl2/MoS2, Ag/AgCl/ Bi6O4(OH)4(NO3)6·H2O have also been reported [144–150]. Apart from the Z-scheme heterojunction, p-n heterojunction and ternary heterojunction, there are numerous studies on conventional binary heterojunctions of PBB photocatalysts. For instance, the combination of PBB photocatalysts with metal oxide (Bi12O17Cl2/WO3 [151], Bi24O31Br10/WO3 [152], Bi12O17Cl2/β-Bi2O3 [153], Bi3O4Br/α-Bi2O3 [154], BiOIO3/Fe2O3 [155], BiOIO3/TiO2 [156], PbBiO2I/PbO [157], Bi24O31Br10/ Cu2O [158], Na3Bi(PO4)2/Ag2O [159]), PBB with BiOX (Bi12O17Cl2/BiOI [70], Bi12O17Cl2/BiOCl [160,161], Bi24O31Br10/ BiOI [162], Bi24O31Br10/BiOBr [163], Bi24O31Cl10/BiOCl [164,165], Bi3O4Br/BiOCl [166], Bi4O5I2/BiOI [167], Bi4O5I2/ Bi5O7I [168], BiOIO3/BiOI [169], BiOIO3/BiOBr [170]) and others heterojunctions (Bi12O17Cl2/AgI [171], Bi3O4Br/AgBr [172], BiOIO3/AgI [173,174], Bi2O2(OH)NO3/AgI [175], Bi4O5I2/C3N4 [176–178], Bi4O5I2/BN [179], Bi4O5I2/Bi5O7I [180], Bi4O5I2/ Bi2S3 [181], Bi2S3/Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) [182], ZnBi2O4/Bi2S3 [183], Bi12O17Cl2/Bi2O2CO3 [184], Bi24O31Br10/Bi12O17Br2 [185], Bi24O31Br10/Bi4V2O11 [186], Bi(C2O4)OH/NaBiO3 [187], BiOIO3/BiOBr0.75I0.25 [188], Bi14MoO24/Bi2O3 [189], BiOIO3/BiVO4 [190], Bi6O6(OH)2(NO3)4·1.5H2O/g-C3N4 [191], PbBiO2I/MoS2 [192], cobalt phthalocyanine/Bi24O31Br10 [193]) have been extensively explored. Magnetically-separable NiFe2O4/ Bi24O31Br10 nanocomposite was designed for the degradation of crystal violet under visible light, demonstrating excellent ferromagnetism and stability [194]. This composite can be easily separated and recycled by a magnet, providing a promising and convenient solution for the large scale wastewaters’ treatment. Homojunction construction between different exposing facets, morphologies and crystal phases of a single semiconductor is a feasible strategy to facilitate the charge transfer [195]. A significant amount of research has been dedicated to the development of homojunction photocatalysts, which have demonstrated exceptional photocatalytic performance. Among different types of homojunctions, facet homojunction is an innovative and appealing strategy for enhancing charge spatial separation by leveraging the distinct properties of different facets. Our group successfully fabricated {010}/{100} BiOIO3 facet junction and {001}/{102}/{112} BiOCl ternary facet junction to observe and research the charge transfer behavior and the influence on the photoredox reactions [196,197]. Inspired by the work of facet junction, BiOIO3 nanosheets exposing appropriate proportion of {010} and {100} facets were synthesized by controlling the HNO3 concentration during the hydrothermal process (Fig. 12(a) ). In this facet junction, {010} facet and {100} facet are reductive facet and oxidative facet, respectively. The facet junction allowed not only enhanced spatial charge carrier separation, but also excellent CO2 reduction performance (Figs. 12(b) and (c)). The eighteen-faceted BiOCl with {001} top facet, {102} oblique facet and {112} side facet was prepared through a prolonged hydrothermal process. The well matched {001}/{102}/{112} ternary facet junction can greatly improve the spatial charge separation and photoredox performance in BiOCl. In conclusion, the construction of heterojunctions photocatalysts which integrate different photocatalysts with distinct catalytic active sites, can effectively utilize the photogenerated charge carriers and facilitate their separation. Among these heterojunctions, conventional binary junctions are more commonly and easily synthesized but exhibit poor separation efficiency of charge carriers. To further improve the charge separation efficiency and photocatalytic activities, Z-scheme and ternary junctions offer greater advantages. However, the formation of heterojunctions between different semiconductors weakens the continuity of charge transfer across semiconductor interfaces. Additionally, fabricating Z-scheme and ternary junctions is crucial and challenging as it significantly relies on matching band structures of the desired semiconductors. Compared to heterojunction photocatalysts, homojunctions with identical components on both sides of the junction offer an incredibly matched lattice, which greatly facilitates the charge transfer with photocatalysts and enhances photocatalytic performances. 4.3 Metal or carbon materials-based composites Noble metals always act as electron acceptors to increase the separation of photoinduced charge carriers, thereby accelerating interfacial charge transfer. The schematic diagram of charge separation of metal/PBB photocatalysts is shown in Fig. 13(a) . Research has shown that Ag/Bi12O17Cl2 and Pt/Bi12O17Cl2 exhibit reinforced visible light photocatalytic activities in the degradation of RhB, 2,4-DCP, MO and phenol [198,199]. The efficient charge separation induced by the localized SPR effect of metallic Ag and Pt significantly enhanced the photocatalytic activity. The loaded Ag and Pt trapped the photoinduced electrons generated from Bi12O17Cl2, effectively inhibiting electron-hole recombination (Fig. 13(b)). Metallic Bi exhibits a similar SPR effect to noble metals but is considerably more cost-effective for surface modification of semiconductors. Additionally, Bi metal can serve as an electron trapper like noble metals to enhance the separation of photoinduced charges. Liu et al. [200] synthesized Bi-Bi4O5I2 with OVs by a one-step solvothermal strategy. The cooperative effect between Bi metal and OVs endowed the samples with significantly enhanced photodegradation performance for BPA and MO under visible light. Another Bi/Bi4O5I2 exhibited an excellent photo-thermal catalytic reduction of CO2 to CO and CH4 under simulated sunlight irradiation (Fig. 13(c)) [68]. Our group discovered that Bi/I− co-decorated BiOIO3 exhibits excellent photooxidation properties towards phenol, 2,4-DCP, RhB, BPA, tetracycline hydrochloride, and NO. [201] The SPR effect caused by metallic Bi enhanced the separation and transformation of photoinduced electrons and holes. Furthermore, the metallic Bi promoted the photoabsorption capacity of photocatalysts, resulting in the generation of more active photoexcitons. Carbon materials such as amorphous biomass carbon materials, 0D carbon quantum dots (CQDs), 1D carbon nanotubes and 2D graphene have garnered significant attention due to their well-defined conjugated sp 2-hybridized carbon structure, large BET surface area and pronounced photoabsorption capabilities. The presence of abundant delocalized electrons in the conjugated sp 2-hybridized structure facilitates the transfer of photogenerated charge carriers. Moreover, the large BET surface area and strong photo-absorption properties contribute to heightened adsorption of reaction molecules and improved photocatalytic performance under visible light. Amorphous biomass carbon materials are commonly used as cost-efficient materials for constructing composite photocatalysts and serving as platforms for transferring photogenerated electrons [204]. The schematic diagram of charge separation of carbon/PBB photocatalysts is illustrated in Fig. 13(d). Bi4O5I2/nitrogen-doped hierarchical carbon composite materials were obtained by carbonizing withered typha grass in ammonia environment, effectively enhancing the charge separation and photocatalytic degradation of MO [205]. Carbon decorated BiOI/BiOIO3 exhibits excellent photocatalytic performance in gas Hg0 removal due to enhanced charge separation through electron transfer from the heterojunction to the carbon material [206]. CQDs always function simultaneously as absorption sites for reaction molecules, transfer sites for photoinduced high-energy electrons, and reaction sites for photocatalytic reactions. A CQDs/Bi4O5I2 material has been prepared and shows superb photodegradation activity (Fig. 13(e)) [202]. The enhancement of performance is because of the rapid transfer and low recombination of photogenerated charges. Additionally, molecular oxygen can be activated through the transfer of electrons from the high-energy CB of Bi4O5I2 to the reaction center CQDs. One-dimensional carbon nanotubes modified Bi12O17Cl2 composite was prepared via a hydrothermal method, demonstrating an improved photocatalytic degradation for RhB [207]. N-doped CQDs modified Bi4O5I2 hollow nanotube photocatalysts demonstrated exceptional photocatalytic activity for BPA removal under a broad spectrum due to the accelerated surface charge transfer by N-doped CQDs (Fig. 13(f)). [203] Graphene-Bi24O31Br10 hierarchical architectures were prepared by a solvothermal process [208]. The tightly coupled Bi24O31Br10 nanosheets with GR showed superior visible light photocatalytic performance in degrading RhB, which can be attributed to enhanced photoabsorption as well as effective charge separation and transfer. ZnBi2O4/RGO performed visible light responsiveness for RhB degradation [124]. Furthermore, BiOIO3/RGO also exhibited improved visible photocatalytic performance in removing NO gas [209]. Constructing composites using metal or carbon materials and PBB photocatalysts is an effective strategy to enhance the separation of photogenerated charge carriers. The enhancement of metal surface modification is primarily due to its plasma effect and carrier separation. Generally, noble metal nanoparticles have a thermal excitation under light irradiation caused by the surface plasma effect, thereby reducing the energy barrier of the reaction and enhancing catalytic activity. Moreover, noble metals possess a high work function, which can serve as excellent electron trapping agents. Fabricating metal and semiconductor composites is conducive to the efficient separation of electrons and holes, thus facilitating photocatalytic activity. Carbon materials possess delocalized π bonds, which can serve as electron trapping agents and facilitate the separation of photogenerated electrons and holes, thereby enhancing photocatalytic performance. However, the incorporation of carbon-based materials with semiconductor materials also presents some drawbacks. For instance, carbon-based materials usually with a large size obstructs light absorption, hampers contact between reactants and the semiconductor surface, weakens the binding energy with the matrix material, and reduces the efficiency of charge transfer. 4.4 Internal electric field (IEF) and polarization electric field (PEF) control Due to the layered structure, many Bi-based materials exhibit an internal electric field (IEF), which facilitates the charge transfer along opposite directions, thus promoting photocatalytic activity. Yu et al. [210] developed a Bi2O2[BO2(OH)]/Bi2O3 heterojunction that demonstrated superior photodegradation of RhB under UV light compared to pure Bi2O3, thanks to the synergetic effect of double IEF, which enhanced charge separation efficiency. 2D and 3D BiOIO3 were prepared at different calcination temperatures, resulting in a closer gathering of internal atoms and the formation of new bonds. This led to shorter atomic spacing and larger IEF in the crystal, ultimately improving the photocatalytic performance for Hg0 removal [211]. Another work with enhanced IEF intensity is achieved through interlining with I− in BiOIO3 [130]. In recent years, PEF has been recognized as an effective and innovative approach to enhance both bulk and surface charge separation (Figs. 14(a) and (b) ) [212,213]. Polarization can manifest in various forms, including macroscopic polarization, piezoelectric polarization, ferroelectric polarization, and surface polarization [214]. Several Sille?n-related and Aurivillius structured PBB photocatalysts have been identified to possess PEF properties, such as BiOIO3, Bi2O2[BO2(OH)] and Bi4Ti3O12 [215]. The polarity of BiOIO3 arises from the alignment of IO3 polyhedra along [001] direction. While the polarity of IO3 polyhedra is canceled out along a and b axis, there is an additive local dipole moment along the c axis. Similarly, in Bi2O2[BO2(OH)], it has been demonstrated that BO2(OH) pyramids exhibit strong local dipole moments. The direction of PEF in Bi2O2[BO2(OH)] is perpendicular to that of IEF. Electrons are primarily generated at the Bi2O2 layers because no B state contribution at the bottom of CB. Meanwhile, holes are captured by BO2(OH) owing to the directionality of PEF. Consequently, electrons and holes are collected at the Bi2O2 layers and BO2(OH) pyramids, respectively, thus improving electron-hole pair separation through PEF [108]. It has been discovered that the control of PEF can be achieved through the manipulation of grain size and doping. BiOIO3 nanoplates, as pyroelectric materials, have been proven to influence the separation of photoinduced charge carriers in photocatalytic H2 production via the PEF effect. Compared to 25 nm nanoplates, BiOIO3 nanoplates with a thickness of 150 nm exhibit a 7-fold increase in H2 evolution, indicating that the thickness of BiOIO3 nanoplates determines the extent of the PEF effect [213]. The PEF effect significantly impacts ion absorption on the surface of BiOIO3 and serves as an accelerator for separating photoinduced carriers. Our group reported vanadium doping to improve the macroscopic polarization of BiOIO3 [216]. To maintain charge conservation, V5+ is selected to replace I5+ in BiOIO3. This replacement leads to an enhancement in macroscopic polarization and a high second harmonic generation response. The process of piezoelectric catalysis and photocatalysis shows significant improvement in separating photoinduced charges, which benefits from enhanced photo- and piezoelectric-induced molecular oxygen activation (Figs. 14(c) and (d)). In summary, the regulation of the IEF or PEF represents an effective and innovative strategy for enhancing both bulk and surface charge separation in most emerging PBB photocatalysts with layered structure and asymmetric centers. Particularly, polarization electric field can serve as a strong driving force to induce the migration of photogenerated electrons and holes in opposite directions. By precisely regulating the bulk phase polarization, surface polarization, and interfacial polarization, piezoelectric polarization, ferroelectric polarization, efficient charge separation of photogenerated species can be achieved, thereby promoting enhanced photocatalytic activity. 4.5 Vacancy defects The introduction of different types of vacancies serves as an effective strategy for enhancing charge separation. Oxygen vacancies (OVs) are considered to be one of the most significant and prevalent anionic defects, due to the relatively low formation energy. OVs have been verified to function as electron trapping centers, effectively capturing and activating reaction molecules like O2, N2, and CO2 owing to the plentiful abundant localized electrons associated with OVs [217]. The presence of OVs in photocatalysts typically results in the creation of an intermediate energy level, resulting in a dispersed energy level in the CB. It effectively enhances electronic conductivity and facilitates the separation of photogenerated carriers. OVs can be introduced into materials through thermal treatment under reductive atmospheres, reduction using chemical reagents, electrochemical reduction, or extraction from plants [218]. There are various techniques available for the detection of OVs, such as EPR, XAFS, XPS and so on. Generally, EPR is capable of detecting OVs containing a single atom with a corresponding g value of typically around 2.001. Furthermore, it allows for quantitative determination of OV concentration through internal standardization and reference samples. XAFS can analyze the bond length between oxygen and metals, providing further insights into coordination due to the presence of unsaturated sites in OVs. In addition, STM imaging of atomic structures enables direct observation of OVs. Lower binding energy metal ion spectra and oxygen spectra obtained from XPS can also be utilized to detect the presence of OVs. Positron annihilation spectrometry is also an effective technique for studying defects in materials by measuring positron lifetimes at the ppm level, valuable information regarding defect/vacancy type and relative concentration can be obtained. Apart from the methods mentioned above, XRD structure refinement and Raman spectroscopy are also capable of detecting OVs. The Bi5O7Br nanotubes with abundant surface OVs are synthesized by light-induced reactions [93]. The presence of low binding energy of Bi in XPS, EPR signal at g = 2.001, and enhanced photoabsorption all confirm the existence of OVs in Bi5O7Br (Figs. 15(a) and (b) ). These light-controlled OVs possess great potential as active sites for N2 photofixation. Moreover, this material exhibits a large surface area and appropriate photoabsorption edge that further enhances its photocatalytic performance. The synthesis of Bi/Bi5O7Br-OVs is achieved using glucose as a reducing agent, which demonstrated superior photocatalytic degradation efficiency towards phenol [219]. Another photocatalyst consisting of Bi4O5I2 nanosheets with OVs was synthesized via solvothermal route and showed enhanced performance for N2 fixation [220]. The presence of OVs leads to an upshift in VB and CB positions while facilitating the formation of a surface-bulk homojunction due to molecular oxygen adsorption; these factors contribute to enhanced separation and transfer efficiency of photoexcited charge carriers. Additionally, OVs exhibit enhancement for photocatalytic Hg0 removal. A calcination method is employed to prepare OV-BiOIO3 [74]. PL spectra were employed to confirm that the presence of OVs benefited charge carrier separation and improved the activity for Hg0 removal during photocatalysis. OV-Bi24O31Cl10 was fabricated by annealing Bi24O31Cl10 under H2/Ar environment [221]. The OVs within Bi24O31Cl10 provide active reaction sites for CO2 molecules and reduce the COOH* formation energy during the CO2 conversion process. In Bi-based photocatalysts, OVs and other vacancies can be united to enhance photocatalytic performance. Flower-like Bi24O31Br10 with OVs and bromine vacancies (BrVs) was successfully fabricated using a microwave-calcination strategy by Xiao et al. [222]. Glucose was employed as a reducing, complexing and structure-composition agent in the synthesis process. The OVs/BrVs-Bi24O31Br10 shows remarkable activity for the photocatalytic aerobic oxidation of benzyl alcohol into benzaldehyde under blue LED irradiation at mild conditions. This excellent activity can be attributed to the presence of OVs and BrVs, which facilitate the capture of photoinduced electrons and dissolved oxygen molecules (O2), leading to improved separation of photoexcited carriers and generation of superoxide radicals (·O2 −) that further react with protons (H+) to produce hydroxyl radicals (·OH). Xia's group constructed Bi3O4Br with co-existing OVs and Bi vacancies by PVP-induced preparation for photocatalytic H2 evolution and N2 fixation [223]. The existence of OVs and BiVs was confirmed by atomic-resolution STEM-HAADF images, XPS, XAS spectra, EPR measurement, and DFT calculation (Figs. 15(c)–(e)). The existence of OVs and BiVs promotes faster and more efficient charge separation as evidenced by ultrafast TA spectroscopy analysis as well as time-resolved transient PL decay measurements. Moreover, the co-vacancy in Bi3O4Br reduces the adsorption energy of N2 molecule while enhancing NH3 generation. The essential role of vacancy defects in photocatalysis is summarized in the aforementioned works. However, most studies are primarily limited to oxygen vacancies. The characterization and effect of photocatalytic reactions of oxygen vacancies have been thoroughly researched. Other vacancies like bromine vacancies and bismuth vacancies also positively contribute to improving photocatalytic activities but with little attention and research. In particular, cation defects have been confirmed to play a crucial role in determining the conductivity of materials, which directly influences the rate of charge carriers’ separation. In addition, multiple vacancies can lead to a larger lattice distortion, which could act as trapping sites to prevent the recombination of charge carriers and adsorption sites to promote photocatalytic reactions. A comprehensive and in-depth insight into these defects and their influence on photocatalysis processes is lacking, which needs more exploration and research to elaborate the internal mechanism. 4.6 Element doping or replacement Element doping and replacement are conventional approaches for enhancing photocatalysis performance. Generally, these methods lead to a reduction in the band gap, thereby enhancing photoabsorption. Additionally, doping elements can effectively trap photoinduced electrons, improving charge carrier separation. The carbon doping strategy employed in Bi-based photocatalysts has been proven to induce an impurity state that promotes the separation and transfer of photoexcited charge carriers. Carbon-doped Bi24O31Cl10 was synthesized via a calcination process with carbon precursor (Fig. 16(a) ) [224]. The presence of doped carbon was confirmed through TG, XPS, and FT-IR analyses, as depicted in Figs. 16(b)–(e). Carbon-doped Bi24O31Cl10 introduces an impurity state near the VB, which serves as charge transport channels for improved charge separation and further enhances CO2 photoreduction activity (Fig. 16(f)). The N-doped BiOIO3 exhibited enhanced photodegradation activities under LED light irradiation. Both the visible light photoabsorption and the generation of photoinduced charge carriers are significantly improved through N doping [225]. Er doped Bi24O31Br10 photocatalysts were synthesized via a solvothermal route [226]. The introduction of Er dopant significantly enhanced the photodegradation of dyes under visible light irradiation. This improvement can be ascribed to the efficient capture of photoexcited electrons by Er3+ ions and subsequent up-conversion process, leading to a remarkable enhancement in photocatalytic performance. The incorporation of Er dopant enables the samples to absorb more low-energy photons due to the abundant energy levels provided by Er3+ ions. Additionally, when higher excited states of Er3+ decay to lower states, high-energy photons are emitted, activating the catalyst and generating additional photoinduced charge carriers. These charge carriers can be effectively separated as a result of trapping photogenerated electrons by Er3+. Furthermore, the band gap is reduced by introducing Er dopant, resulting in an enhanced photoresponse. Moreover, I− ions enter into the crystal lattices of Bi12O17Cl2 and create impurity levels above the valence band, thereby broadening its visible light absorption range [227]. The doping with I− in Bi12O17Cl2 promotes charge separation and enhances photocatalytic activities for MO and phenol degradation. Interlayer-I-doped BiOIO3 nanoplates were synthesized by Dong's group and demonstrated efficient photocatalytic removal of NO gas under visible light irradiation [228]. Experimental results and theoretical calculations confirmed that the introduction of I− ions creates an intermediate energy level within the BiOIO3 structure, thereby broadening its photoresponse range (Figs. 16(g)–(i)). Bi24O31Cl x Br10–x solid solutions were prepared using a solvothermal approach for the first time [229]. Among various Bi24O31Cl x Br10–x samples, Bi24O31Cl5Br5 exhibited the highest photodegradation performance of RhB and phenol under visible light. This improved photocatalytic performance can be ascribed to its suitable band gap, efficient photoabsorption, and effective separation and transfer of photoinduced charge carriers. By adjusting the Br/I molar ratio, the band gap of Bi4O5Br x I2–x photocatalysts can be tuned. Specifically, Bi4O5Br0.6I1.4 demonstrated superior photocatalytic performance in degrading certain phenols [230]. Element doping is a widely employed modification strategy for photocatalysts. Metal and non-metal doping typically give rise to new hybrid states and doping levels, effectively suppressing photogenerated carrier recombination while narrowing the band gap width to enhance light absorption range of photocatalysts. However, due to the composition of valence band hybrid orbitals in most Bi-based materials, metal doping significantly influences the conduction band position, whereas non-metal doping generally replaces oxygen positions, thereby affecting valence band hybrid orbitals. Therefore, the photooxidation and reduction performances of emerging PBB photocatalysts can be selectively regulated by controlling the band position through metal or non-metal doping. 4.7 Surface modification Surface modification strategies, such as surface decoration with ions (Cl, Br and I), the control of surface basic and acid site, and conjugated polymer (polyaniline, polypyrrole, polythiophene, provide an efficient approach to regulate band gap, tailor optical properties and enhance photocatalytic performance of photocatalysts. These strategies have been proven effective in achieving visible light response for numerous photocatalysts [231]. A series of adjustable band gap iodine modified BiOIO3 materials were prepared via an in-situ reduction method by our group, using glucose as reducing agent [232]. By controlling the glucose concentration, the band gap of these I-BiOIO3 could be orderly narrowed, resulting in the formation of impurity or defect energy levels below the CB, thereby ensuring their visible light response. The introduction of iodine significantly enhances the photodegradation performance of RhB, MO and ppb-level NO under visible light. PANI decorated Bi12O17Cl2 exhibits enhanced degradation of CIP compared to pure Bi12O17Cl2 [233]. The presence of PANI not only broadens the absorption range of visible light but also promotes charge separation, as the photogenerated e− on the LUMO of PANI can be transferred to the CB of Bi12O17Cl2. A surface halogenation strategy was employed over Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) to enhance CO2 photoreduction by our group [234]. Surface halogen ions (Cl−, Br− and I−) were anchored onto the Bi atoms by replacing surface hydroxyls, activating them and promoting CO2 adsorption while enhancing local charge separation. EDX element maps and XPS spectra with Ar+ sputtering at different times confirmed the presence of Br− ions on the surface (Figs. 17(a), (b) ). The surface modification of Br− greatly promotes the separation of photogenerated charge carriers (Fig. 17(c)). Furthermore, there is an increased charge density between Br atom and Bi atom compared to OH and Bi atom and an increased charge density for CO2 and H+ absorbed Bi2O2(OH)(NO3)-Br (Figs. 17(d), (e)). Surface basic site modification is a novel and efficient strategy for enhancing photocatalytic activity. Su et al. discovered that surface basic sites on Bi24O31Br10(OH) δ accelerated photoredox reactions when compared with acidified Bi24O31Br10 [235,236]. The existence of basic site was confirmed by XPS and CO2-IR, where O 1s XPS spectra showed a strong –OH signal peak. Moreover, a more intense CO2 desorption peak indicates an increase in basic sites, which benefits photocatalytic reactions. These basic sites act as proton extractors on the surface of catalyst, greatly enhancing hydrogen extraction from hydrogen donors under irradiation, thereby improving photocatalytic activity (Fig. 17(c)). The surface modification strategy offers a strategy to regulate the charge separation at the surface or interface of semiconductor materials and facilitate the construction of surface active sites. The electric conductivity of organics differs significantly from that of metals; however, organics also exhibit a certain capacity for electron trapping and can serve as an effective electron-trapping agent in photocatalysts. Therefore, the photocatalytic performance can be enhanced by surface modification of organics by utilizing the properties of electron trapping, and the unique adsorption and selectivity of reactants. Surface modification with nonmetallic elements has the potential to alter local electron distribution and adsorption sites, thereby influencing catalytic performance. 5 Application of emerging PBB Photocatalysts 5.1 Pollutant control As a result of the continuously rising environmental pollution caused by anthropogenic activities, particularly the environmental problems triggered by different pollutants, the advancement of photocatalysts for pollutant decomposition has emerged as a promising approach to alleviate this crisis [237,238].
