Almost all the photocatalysts could degrade dyes under UV or visible light irradiation. The photoexcited holes and electrons participate in reduction or oxidation reaction with H2O and O2, generating reactive oxygen species ·OH and ·O2 − that react with pollutant molecules. Many PBB photocatalysts have more positive CB and VB positions, resulting in a relatively strong oxidative ability and weak reductive ability. Fig. 18 illustrates the main pollutants degraded by PBB photocatalysts, containing phenols, dyes, drugs and other gaseous pollutants. Numerous PBB photocatalysts exhibit excellent performance in degrading various liquid pollutants such as RhB [85,107,108,210], MB [52,76,78], MO [43,49,239], Acid Red 1 [116], tetracycline [239,240], phenol [43], bisphenol A [239], 2,4-dichlorophenol [36], resorcinol [241], crystal violet [30,107], sulfamethazine [171], sodium pentachlorophenate [24], salicylic acid [103], 4-tert-butylphenol [26], ciprofloxacin [102], Perfluorooctanoic Acid [84] and gaseous pollutants like NO gas [96,161,177] and gaseous Hg0. [133,146,156,206,242,243] Among them, Bi24O31Br10 and Bi12MnO20 presents superb photocatalytic reduction performance of the Cr(VI) [72,99]. 5.2 Water splitting H2 is widely recognized as an efficient and environmentally friendly clean energy source due to the high energy density and pollution-free after combustion. Extensive research has been conducted on photocatalytic H2 production since the initial breakthrough in photocatalytic water splitting by using TiO2 [244]. Photocatalytic water splitting for H2 production has proven to be an effective strategy for solving energy issues and can be separated into half and overall water splitting. A suitable position of the band position of photocatalysts to achieve water splitting is highly required. Although numerous PBB photocatalysts have been utilized in recent years, their application is greatly limited. Most of these photocatalysts are employed for pollutant control, with insufficient exploration in other applications like water splitting, CO2 reduction and N2 fixation. The crucial factors determining the efficacy of photocatalysts are the band gap and the positions of CB and VB. In order to achieve efficient water splitting, the CB position should be more negative than 0V (vs. NHE, pH = 0), while the VB position needs to be more positive than 1.23 V (vs. NHE, pH = 0) due to the redox potential of H+/H2 at 0 V (vs. NHE, pH = 0) and O2/H2O at 1.23 V (vs. NHE, pH = 0). Consequently, the theoretical minimum band gap required for water splitting is 1.23 eV (Fig. 19(a) ). Many PBB photocatalysts exhibit excellent oxygen production performance owing to their relatively low VB positions. In the aforementioned novel photocatalysts, only several PBB photocatalysts like Bi24O31Br10, Bi4O5 X 2 (X = Br, I) and Bi4NbO8Br demonstrated excellent performance in water splitting for hydrogen production. Until now, previous studies have shown that BiOBr and BiOI are not suitable for photocatalytic H2 evolution due to their positive CB position. Nevertheless, some Bi x O y X z photocatalysts with more negative CB positions have been designed and utilized successfully for photocatalytic H2. Notably, Bi24O31Br10 material has been investigated and exhibits remarkable activity in photo splitting H2O into H2 at a rate of 3.3475 μmol h−1 and excellent stability under visible light irradiation [99]. Bi4O5 X 2 (X = Br, I) with exposed {101} facets prepared by Ye's group displayed efficient water splitting activity for H2 generation [245]. The H2 production rate of Bi4O5Br2 reaches 6.81 μmol h−1 with the apparent quantum efficiency (AQE) of 0.93% at 420 nm when using a solution containing 40% CH3OH compared to only an AQE of 0.52% for Bi4O5I2. Furthermore, Bi4NbO8Br demonstrated superb performance in photocatalytic H2 production under visible light [246]. The highest H2 production rate was obtained in a glycerol solution reaching 29.5 μmol h−1 with approximately a QE of 0.4% at 420 nm. Water splitting for O2 evolution is challenging due to the four-electron oxidation of water. Sillén-Aurivillius structured PBB materials were verified to exhibit superior photocatalytic O2 evolution activities. Kunioku et al. [62] discovered Bi6NbWO14Cl is a steady O2-evolving photocatalyst in Z-scheme water splitting under visible light. The apparent quantum yield (AQY) reached 1.4% and 0.4% at 420 nm in AgNO3(aq) and FeCl3(aq), respectively. Subsequently, a Z-scheme system consisting of Bi6NbWO14Cl/Ru-loaded SrTiO3:Rh was constructed to achieve overall water splitting, resulting in the stable production of H2 and O2 in a stoichiometric ratio. After reaction for 40 h, the generation of O2 reached 101 μmol (Fig. 19(b)). Among PbBiO2 X (X = Cl, Br and I), PbBiO2Cl exhibited the best performance for photocatalytic water oxidation approximately 2.5 μmol h−1 O2 under visible light irradiation [105]. Bi4(Nb, Ta)O8(Cl, Br), a type of visible-light-responsive photocatalysts, performed excellent activity for water oxidation [247]. The O2 generation rate of Bi4NbO8Br was approximately 2 μmol h−1 in FeCl3 solution under visible light. The overall water splitting process using a single photocatalyst is highly challenging. Bi2Ga4O9 photocatalyst developed by Yang et al. [65] exhibited remarkable performance in terms of overall water splitting efficiency. Various cocatalysts such as Pt, RuO x , or NiO x have also been extensively investigated. Among them, when RuO x is used as a co-catalyst, and the optimal rates of H2 and O2 generation are measured to be 41.5 and 19.6 μmol h−1 g−1 respectively (Fig. 19(d)). The AQY at 420 nm reaches 0.09%. Abe's group developed a series of Sille?n-Aurivillius oxychloride and used them for water splitting for H2 or O2 [60,115]. They found Bi5SrTi3O14Cl exhibited higher activity for O2 evolution than Bi5PbTi3O14Cl, due to the detrimental effect of Pb2+ on the photocatalytic activity. Then they constructed a Z-scheme water splitting system under visible light by using (Fe/Ru)O x /Bi5SrTi3O14Cl and Ru/SrTiO3:Rh as O2 and H2 evolving photocatalysts, respectively. In addition, they fabricated photocatalysts for water splitting and H2/O2 generation by incorporating varying numbers of perovskite layers in Sille?n-Aurivillius oxychlorides BaBi5Ti3O14Cl (n = 5), Ba2Bi5Ti4O17Cl (n = 4) and Ba3Bi5Ti5O20Cl (n = 5) [61]. The results demonstrated that the photocatalytic activities exhibit an improvement as the number of the perovskite layers increases. Bi2CrO6, with a direct bandgap of 1.86 eV, was reported that exhibits efficient activities for photocatalytic water oxidation and H2 production under visible light [109]. Additionally, a sustainable Z-scheme system for overall water splitting was constructed by coupling triclinic Bi2CrO6 as the O2 evolution photocatalyst with SrTiO3:Rh as the H2 evolution photocatalyst, yielding stable overall water splitting with stoichiometric generation of H2 and O2 (Figs. 19(c) and (d)). 5.3 CO2 reduction The excessive combustion of fossil fuels caused excess emission of CO2. Given the global commitment to reduce CO2 emissions and combat climate change, as well as energy security, there is great promise in developing clean and sustainable energy to convert CO2 into value-added fuels (like CO, CH4 and HCOOH) and chemicals [248]. CO2 molecule contains two C=O bonds arranged in a linear configuration. These C=O bonds exhibit exceptional stability, with a dissociation energy of approximately 750 kJ mol−1, indicating the presence of a significant activation barrier for CO2 activation and C=O bond cleavage [249]. Furthermore, considering the highest chemical state of the carbon atom in CO2, the reduction of CO2 can yield diverse complex products such as CO, CH4, HCOOH, CH3OH, and HCHO. The thermodynamic redox potentials (vs. NHE at pH = 7) for various products resulting from CO2 reduction are illustrated in Fig. 20(a) . In the process of photocatalytic CO2 reduction, light absorption, CO2 capture and chemical conversion of CO2 are three key processes [250]. In this regard, many kinds of emerging PBB materials are attractive candidates for photocatalytic CO2 reduction. In the aforementioned PBB photocatalysts, many kinds of materials were investigated for CO2 photoreduction activity. The reaction condition and performance of photocatalytic CO2 reduction of PBB photocatalysts are shown in Table 2 . Our group reported a ferroelectric polarization strategy to enhance the bulk charge separation for remarkably improving the CO2 photoreduction performance of SrBi4Ti4O15 for the first time [55]. The ferroelectric polarization in SrBi4Ti4O15 originates from TiO6 octahedra and the spontaneous polarization cumulates along an a-axis due to the distortion orientation of TiO6 octahedra along [100] direction, forming a giant polarization. Benefiting from the spontaneous polarization, SrBi4Ti4O15 exhibited an excellent photocatalytic CO2 reduction activity (Fig. 20(b)). In-situ DRIFTS was employed to research the conversion mechanism for interfacial changes during CO2 reduction process (Fig. 20(c)). Ultrathin 2D structured Pb0.6Bi1.4O2Cl1.4 was utilized for photocatalytic atmospheric CO2 reduction, with reduction products of CO, CH3OH and CH4 (Fig. 20(d)) [42]. The product of CH3OH is approximately 26.53 umol g−1, which is 7.3 times higher than that of Pb0.6Bi1.4Cs0.6O2Cl2 precursor. 13C and 18O isotopic tracing experiments confirmed the carbon and oxygen sources (Fig. 20(e)). Differential charge density reveals that Bi atoms with high electron density show a strong electrostatic attraction towards CO2 molecules (Fig. 20(f)). The CO2 reduction rate of Bi4O5I2 under 420 nm monochromatic light irradiation was found to be much higher (19.82 umol h−1 g−1) compared to that of Bi5O7I (1.73 umol h−1 g−1) [25]. Additionally, Bi/Bi4O5I2 composites showed exceptional photo-thermal catalytic performance in converting CO2 to both CO (40.02 umol h−1 g−1) and CH4 performance (7.19 umol h−1 g−1) under UV-vis-IR irradiation [68]. Bi24O31Br10 embedded with cobalt phthalocyanine exhibits superb activity in the photoreduction of CO2 to methanol [193]. The reaction was conducted using DMF as the reaction medium, water as a proton donor, and TEA as the sacrificial electron donor. The highest methanol generation rate was 145.2 μmol h−1 g−1. Bi24O31Cl10 with OVs and carbon doped Bi24O31Cl10 exhibited remarkable CO2 reduction activities [224]. OVs reduced the formation energy of COOH*, facilitating its conversion to CO during the reduction process. Carbon doping introduces an impurity state near the VB, promoting charge carrier separation. Bi12O17Cl2 with an adequate number of surface OVs exhibited remarkable activity in reducing CO2 [251]. The rate of CO generation reached 48.6 μmol h−1 g−1, which was 16.8 times higher than that observed for bulk Bi12O17Cl2. The presence of OVs enhances the absorption and activates the CO2 molecule. Our group has employed a surface hydrogenation strategy to achieve a significant improvement in CO2 photoreduction efficiency. By modifying the surface with Br− ions, the production rate of CO on Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) reaches 8.12 μmol h−1 g−1, which is 74-fold higher than that of pure Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) [234]. The theoretical calculations indicate an enhanced charge density between the Br atom and Bi atom, as well as increased adsorption energy of CO2 and H+. Activation of neighboring OH groups and facilitation of local charge separation promotes the photoreduction activity of CO2. Additionally, considerable ·O2 − and ·OH are generated by BiOIO3, effectively enhancing the CO2 photoreduction activity [197,252]. By constructing a {010}/{100} facet junction in BiOIO3, spatial separation of photoexcited charge carriers is achieved, further improving the performance of CO2 reduction. The highest CO evolution rate over BiOIO3 facet junction reaches 5.42 µmol g−1 h−1, over 300% that of the bulk BiOIO3 (1.77 µmol g−1 h−1). 5.4 N2 fixation Ammonia, an indispensable ingredient in the fertilizer industry crucial for sustained human survival, is currently primarily synthesized through the Haber-Bosch process. However, due to the harsh processing conditions (400–500 °C, 150–250 atm), this industrial method requires substantial energy inputs [276]. Therefore, it's imperative to explore a more environment-friendly approach for sustainable NH3 production. Photocatalytic N2 fixation offers a promising way by enabling ammonia under mild conditions and holds significant potential in addressing the energy problem if efficient photocatalysts are employed [277]. Photocatalytic N2 fixation for Bi-based photocatalysts has emerged as a novel application in recent years. However, achieving this process and meeting the requirements remains highly challenging due to the inherent difficulty in activating and cleaving the highly stable N≡N triple bond (bond energy: 940.95 kJ mol−1), along with the presence of various intermediates during the reaction. The following formulas reflect the potential for reduction of N2 to various products (vs. NHE at pH = 0). (1) N2(g) + 6H+(aq) → 2NH3(g) E 0 RHE = –0.05 V (2) N2(g) + 4OH−(aq) → 2NO(g) + 2H2O(l) E 0 RHE = 0.85 V (3) N2(g) + 6OH−(aq) → 2NO2(g) + 2H2O(l) E 0 RHE = 0.54 V Photocatalytic N2 fixation performances of PBB photocatalysts are shown in Table 3 . However, only a limited number of Sillén-structured PBB photocatalysts have been investigated for their photocatalytic N2 fixation performance. The N≡N triple bond can be opened by incorporating electron capturing centers as active sites to trap molecular N2 and weaken the N≡N bond. Bi5O7Br nanotubes with OVs were fabricated, exhibiting stable photoreduction performance for converting N2 to NH3 in pure water [93]. Compared to BiOBr-OVs, Bi5O7Br-OVs demonstrated an excellent NH3 generation rate of 1.38 mmol h−1 g−1 with an AQE of 2.3% at 420 nm (Fig. 21(a) ). In-situ DRFTIRS spectra revealed that the presence of OVs weakened the N≡N triple bonds, leading to their continuous conversion into NH3 and NH4 +. Isotopic labeling experiments confirmed that the N element in NH3 originated from N2 (Fig. 21(b)). The overall process of photocatalytic N2 fixation involves four steps, firstly, under visible light irradiation, some O atoms are released as O2 from Bi5O7Br-NT surface generating sufficient surface OVs; secondly, chemisorption and activation of N2 occur on the OV sites; thirdly, photoinduced electrons inject into activated N2 and reduce it to NH3; finally, after reaction completion, photoinduced OVs are replenished by capturing O atoms from water resulting in a restored OV-free material. Xiong's group also synthesized OVs-Bi5O7Br for N2 fixation, and conducted calculations on the adsorption free energy of N2 and reaction energy of the N2 fixation pathway, thereby confirming the key role of OVs in the adsorption and activation of N2 (Figs. 21(c) and (d)) [278]. Bi4O5I2 with surface OVs also exhibited enhanced activity of N2 fixation, as evidenced by the attainment of NH3 concentrations exceeding 30 μmol L−1 within 80 min [220]. The presence of Bi and O co-vacancies in the Bi3O4Br significantly boosted N2 fixation capability, leading to a measured NH3 amount of 25.4 μmol L−1 h−1 (Fig. 21(e)) [223]. In-situ FTIR was used to investigate the adsorption, activation, and reaction process of N2 (Fig. 21(f)). 5.5 Selective organic synthesis Photocatalysis technology is widely recognized as a sustainable and reliable approach for achieving selective organic synthesis. In recent years, significant attention has been devoted to the development of organic synthesis methods for converting oxidizing alcohols into relevant aldehydes. Notably, Bi12O17Cl2 and Bi24O31Br10 demonstrated superior performance in selectively oxidizing benzyl alcohol (BA). Under visible light irradiation, Bi12O17Cl2 nanobelts exhibit remarkable efficiency and selectivity in transforming BA into benzaldehyde (BAD) through direct hole oxidation [32]. The selectivity can reach 41.0% when air is used as an oxidant. The positions of CB and VB for Bi12O17Cl2 are –0.34 and 2.09 eV, respectively, and the reduction potentials of O2/·O2 −, BA/BAD and BAD/oxidized BAD are determined to be −0.33, 1.98 and 2.5 eV. It indicates that Bi12O17Cl2 can effectively meet the three reduction potentials, making it an attractive photocatalyst for selective oxidation of BA under visible light. Additionally, the micro/nano-architecture structure, surface defects and positively charge surface also play crucial roles in facilitating the reaction process. The Bi24O31Cl10/BiOCl composite also displays superb photocatalytic efficiency (40.3%) and selectivity (> 99%) towards the oxidation of BA to BAD under visible light irradiation. In the photocatalytic conversion process, photogenerated holes serve as the primary active species for the oxidation of BA [164]. Su et al. [235] discovered that surface basic site on Bi24O31Br10(OH) δ can accelerate photoredox reactions for selective organic synthesis under visible light and ambient conditions, such as BA to BAD, nitrobenzene to azo/azoxybenzene, quinones to quinols, thiones to thiols, and alcohols to ketones (Figs. 22(a) and (b) ). The presence of basic sites in Bi24O31Br10(OH) δ was confirmed by O 1s spectra in XPS. The observation of –OH vibrational peak during CD3OD photo-oxidation process confirms the coordination between D atoms and O atoms in Bi24O31Br10(OH) δ (Fig. 22(c)). Bi24O31Br10(OH) δ exhibited the highest photo-oxidation of 1-octanol performance among a series of Bi-relevant photocatalysts (Fig. 22(d)) [235,236]. Bi24O31Br10 demonstrated excellent photocatalytic activity for selective oxidation of BA to BAD with a conversion rate exceeding 99% under blue LED irradiation at ambient conditions, which is 3.3, 4.7, and 27.8 times compared with TiO2, Bi4O5Br2, and Bi12O17Cl2, respectively [222]. These remarkable selectivity and conversion rates are attributed to its suitable band gap (E g = 2.51 eV), VB position (VB = 2.38 V), and efficient separation of photogenerated charges. 5.6 H2 generation from H2S H2S is produced in large quantities by the coal and petroleum industries and it is an environmental pollutant due to its corrosive and acidic properties. Therefore, it is crucial and necessary to rationally utilize or remove H2S. In addition to water splitting for H2 generation, H2S has been identified as an alternative source for H2 production because the energy required for H2S splitting (79.9 kJ mol−1) is much lower than that for water splitting (284.7 kJ mol−1). Moreover, utilizing H2S splitting for H2 production can simultaneously address environmental pollution control and sustainable energy resource needs. Thus, developing new visible light responsive photocatalysts for efficient H2S splitting to generate H2 offers a promising solution to these environmental issues. The dissociation of H2S undergoes two acid dissociation reactions at a pH of 13.5, resulting in the formation of HS− and S2− in equilibrium. The generated HS− and S2− then react with photoinduced holes to produce S2 2− and H+, which subsequently interact with photoinduced electrons to generate H2. The continuous reaction processes can be represented by the following equations: (3) H2S + OH− ↔ HS− + H2O (1) 2HS− + 2h+ VB → S2 2− + 2H+ (4) H2S + OH− ↔ S2− + H2O (2) 2S2− + 2h+ VB → S2 2− (5) 2H+ + 2e− CB → H2 CdBi2Nb2O9 has been reported to be an excellent photocatalyst with the highest rate of 13824 μmol h−1 g−1 for producing H2 from H2S. This exceptional performance can be attributed to the porous structure, small particle size, and high surface area of the samples synthesized using the combustion method [53]. The VB top of CdBi2Nb2O9 consists of hybridized Bi 6s, Cd 4s, and O 2p orbitals which result in a narrowed band gap. The hybridized s and p orbitals show large dispersion leading to increased mobility of photoexcited electrons in CB, thereby enabling high photocatalytic activity. 5.7 Other applications Dye sensitization is a highly efficient method for expanding the spectral responsive range of wide bandgap materials in photocatalytic reactions. Visible light is absorbed by dye molecules, leading to photoexcited electrons transferring from the highest occupied molecular orbital (HOMO) to the lowest unoccupied molecular orbital (LUMO) of the dye. Consequently, electrons on the LUMO of dyes are injected into the CB of photocatalysts, causing the conversion of the dye itself into cationic radicals, as depicted in Fig. 23(a) . Visible light responsive photocatalyst Bi24O31Cl10 exhibits remarkable RhB photodegradation activity through dye sensitization [33]. Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) nanosheets also exhibit an enhancement of dye-sensitization degradation performance under visible light by using RhB as a sensitized medium to generate photogenerated electrons (Figs. 23(b)–(d)) [239]. Molecular oxygen (O2) plays a key role in photocatalytic reactions. However, O2 cannot oxidize most organic pollutants due to the spin forbidden reactions. The reactive oxygen species (ROS), such as superoxide (·O2 −), hydroxyl radical (·OH), singlet oxygen (1O2) and hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) are the primary reactive species responsible for pollutant degradation in photocatalytic reactions [281]. The generation reaction can be simply described as shown in Fig. 24(a) . O2 activation occurs when photoexcited electrons on the surface of photocatalysts react with O2 or H2O, leading to the further generation of H2O2 or 1O2. Therefore, improving ROS generation is necessary and critical for successful photocatalysis. Bi2O2(OH)(NO3) nanosheets with exposed {001} active facet were prepared by our group. The photocatalytic performance was evaluated based on the production rates of active species ·O2 − and ·OH, which were measured as 3.14 and 0.03 μmol L−1 min−1 [239]. Bi24O31Br10 nanobelt exhibited a strong response to visible light and demonstrated high activity in generating ·OH and ·O2 − (Figs. 24(b) and (c)) [282]. Similarly, Bi24O31Cl10 nanosheets with exposed (001) facets also displayed superior photocatalytic activities compared to BiOCl for activating molecular oxygen under visible light to generate ·O2 −, as well as generating ·OH under UV-vis light [97]. 6 Conclusions and future perspectives 6.1 Conclusions This review provides a relatively comprehensive summary of the recent advances in emerging Bi-based photocatalysts that have been reported over the past decade, encompassing aspects from the crystal structure (including Sille?n, Sille?n-related, Aurivillius, Sille?n-Aurivillius and other structures), synthesis methodologies, modification strategies (such as morphology control, active facet exposure, heterojunction construction involving metal or carbon materials, internal polar electric field manipulation, oxygen vacancies, doping or element substitution and surface modification), as well as diverse applications. For example, a comprehensive and intuitive understanding of synthesis method and modification strategies of emerging PBB photocatalysts can be obtained. In the section of applications, the overall products and the yield of photocatalytic CO2 reduction and nitrogen fixation can be grasped. Through this comprehensive review, a deep insight into crystal structure and development in the field of photocatalysis over emerging PBB photocatalysts can be swiftly obtained. 6.2 Future perspectives According to this review, several aspects may drive further developments in the field of emerging PBB photocatalysts. (1) Most of the PBB photocatalysts exhibit a relatively wide band gap, resulting in limited absorption of visible light. Additionally, they possess relatively positive CB and VB positions. It sheds light on the research trend focused on enhancing their visible light absorption capability and robust oxidative ability. Various modification strategies can be employed to augment their response to visible light. (2) Active facets play a crucial role in the photocatalytic process. Photocatalysts with exposed active facets have been confirmed to exhibit exceptional performance attributed to their unique surface electronic structures and surface states. Further exploration is required for synthesizing methods and facet engineering of PBB photocatalysts, specifically focusing on the active facets. (3) There are numerous modification methods available to enhance the photocatalytic performance. Homojunctions refer to junctions fabricated using the same materials but with different crystal phases, semiconductor types, or exposed facets without incorporating other elements. The construction of homojunctions is a highly promising strategy for improving photocatalytic activity. However, among these PBB photocatalysts, only a few facet junctions have been fabricated to investigate charge separation. Further exploration of homojunctions is necessary to enhance photocatalytic performance. (4) Polarization electric field engineering represents a novel approach to enhance photocatalysis. Partial Bi-based photocatalysts with Sille?n-related and Aurivillius structures possess polar crystal structures and polarization electric fields. The regulation of this electric field can result in an enhanced separation of bulk charge and surface charge through the utilization of macroscopic, piezoelectric, ferroelectric, and surface modification techniques. Therefore, utilizing polarization electric fields to augment the photocatalytic performance is becoming a prominent trend. (5) Although various photocatalytic applications have been explored, the potential applications of each photocatalyst are still limited and require further exploration. Currently, the focus of most PBB photocatalysts remains on pollutant degradation, while other applications such as water splitting, nitrogen fixation, and CO2 reduction are lacking. These materials hold potential for further exploration in terms of their applications. Additionally, photogenerated electrons and holes have strong reduction and oxidation activities. However, in most current reaction systems, electrons and holes are selectively utilized in a single reduction or oxidation reaction, resulting in a significant depletion of energy. It has great potential to employ a photocatalytic system to achieve simultaneous reduction and oxidation reactions, like photocatalytic oxidation of organic pollutants combined with H2 generation, photocatalytic CO2 reduction in conjunction with oxidation of organic substrates/biomass to value-added products and so on. The challenging point in this complex system is the appropriate semiconductor photocatalysts. Most emerging PBB photocatalysts possess formidable strong oxidation ability, thereby showcasing the tremendous potential for constructing heterojunctions with materials that possess strong reduction abilities to achieve dual-functional simultaneous processes. (6) The traditional Bi-based materials have been applied in the fields of electrocatalysis, thermal catalysis, battery technology and so on. With the emergence of novel Bi-based photocatalytic materials, they can also be effectively expanded to these domains. Overall, the development of novel Bi-based photocatalysts remains a highly intriguing research area, with the potential for these innovative polynary Bi-based catalysts to find broader applications across various fields in the future. This review provides a comprehensive summary and offers an insight into future research trends of emerging PBB photocatalysts and guidance for finding potential applications based on their crystal structures. Shixin Yu is a lecturer at Beijing Key Laboratory of Lignocellulosic Chemistry, Beijing Forestry University. He graduated from China University of Geosciences (Beijing) with a doctorate in Materials Science and Technology in 2020. His research interests focus on lignocellulosic biomass high-value utilization and photocatalytic conversion for sustainable materials and chemicals. Hongwei Huang is a professor at Beijing Key Laboratory of Materials Utilization of Nonmetallic Minerals and Solid Wastes, School of Materials Science and Technology, China University of Geosciences (Beijing). He received his Ph.D. in 2012 from the Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, and worked as a visiting scholar in the lab of Prof. Thomas Mallouk at The Pennsylvania State University (2016–2017). His current research mainly focuses on the crystal structural design and charge regulation of polar photocatalysts and their applications for energy and environment.

coredata.dc:description: Photocatalysis is widely recognized as a promising technique for addressing energy and environmental challenges. Exploring novel photocatalysts represents a crucial avenue for advancing the development of photocatalytic technology. Bismuth (Bi)-based photocatalysts have garnered significant attention due to their distinctive crystal structure, favorable hybrid electronic band structure and diverse composition. In recent years, numerous polynary Bi-based (PBB) photocatalysts have been investigated, which exhibit excellent photocatalytic performance. However, most reviews still primarily focus on summarizing traditional materials, it is necessary and urgent to provide a comprehensive review of emerging PBB photocatalysts reported in recent years. This review encompasses the latest advancements in emerging PBB photocatalysts over the past decade (approximately 60 species), covering crystal structure, synthesis method, modification approaches and application areas. This review provides a concise summary and offers insight into future research trends of emerging PBB photocatalysts and guidance for finding suitable applications based on their crystal structures.

coredata.dc:title: Emerging polynary bismuth-based photocatalysts: Structural classification, preparation, modification and applications
